If we, the Senate, decide that the rules governing the conciliation of complaints are wrong and should be changed, and have made that decision, then of course the new rules, the reformed rules, that the Senate in its wisdom has decided ought to be given effect to should apply to current complaints as well.

So you do not make a principle objection at all, Senator, but you say, 'Well, this might impose an administrative burden on the Human Rights Commission.' I am bound to say, for a body that, to the best of my recollection, receives about $26 million a year in taxpayer funding, I do not think that, frankly, to expect the commission to do an audit of its current complaints for compliance with the new rules is unreasonable at all or that it imposes an unendurable administrative burden. We have debated those sections of the bill that are in controversy. It may have escaped the attention of those following the debate, but it should not have, but many of the measures the government is proposing have been uncontroversial and therefore they have not been subject to any discussion in this debate. But the effect of most of those measures, in particular the measures proposed by Professor Triggs in her letter to me of April 2015, was to relieve the Human Rights Commission of administrative burdens, to relieve the Human Rights Commission of a huge number of unnecessary administrative burdens. So what this legislation in fact is doing is freeing up the Human Rights Commission of the administrative burdens that they themselves have pointed to and asked to be excused from, and the government has agreed. If in a transition period from the old arrangements to the new arrangements the Human Rights Commission, which is now free of all these other administrative burdens, has to conduct an audit of its current complaints to see if they are compliant with the new rules, then that is no more than any government and the public ought reasonably to expect from any public agency.

Senator McKIM (Tasmania) (11:56): I need to respond to the Attorney so that people listening and watching can actually understand the crux of this issue, which the Attorney-General has glossed over in his previous contribution. I want to be clear about this, and the Attorney has not rebutted this by the way, nor rejected it: this will place a significant burden on the Human Rights Commission. In his previous contribution, the Attorney effectively confessed that he agrees to that, because he said—
Senator O'Sullivan: Why are you dragging this debate out?
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: Order, Senator O'Sullivan!
Senator McKIM: The bill steam shovel is still going over there!
Senator O'Sullivan: What about the people in the process. This is outrageous. What have you got against natural justice.
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: Senator O'Sullivan, you will assist the chair by desisting from any comments.

Senator McKIM: The Attorney firstly cannot tell us how many complaints are currently afoot. I find that extraordinary. It shows how out of touch with his portfolio he actually is. But he has effectively confessed that this will place a significant burden on the commission, because he has accepted that they will need to audit the entirety of their caseload. No-one has said that this is not possible—I want to be clear about that. But what we have said, and it has not been rebutted by the Attorney—and I would like him to respond to this—is that when you have a commission that has a finite body of resources, whether they be human or financial, imposing a significant burden of reviewing every single one of what I believe are likely to be thousands of cases currently afoot at the commission will inevitably mean that the normal business of the commission, which is to progress the cases that are afoot, will be compromised by the need to conduct the audit that the Attorney has accepted that the commission will need to do if this amendment is successful. So this is retrospectivity that he is imposing on the commission. In any reasonable definition this is retrospectivity. He is asking the commission to change the way they are proceeding in relation to matters that were lodged with them before the law was changed, if in fact it does get changed as a result of this amendment. So we are strongly opposed to this. Again, it appears vindictive in the extreme that the Attorney is proposing.

Senator BRANDIS (Queensland—Attorney-General, Vice-President of the Executive Council and Leader of the Government in the Senate) (11:59): Again, that is such a foolish contribution. Senator McKim, for a start it is absurd to say that this is retrospective. Legislation is retrospective only if it alters pre-existing rights and liabilities, and nobody has suggested that this legislation does that. So your suggestion that it operates retrospectively is absurd.

Secondly, what we are talking about is a transition period between an existing set of arrangements and a new and more efficient set of arrangements, because it is not disputed by anyone that the new arrangements, which the Senate has agreed to, will make the Human Rights Commission work more efficiently and will take an administrative burden from their shoulders. So, in transitioning from an old and burdensome set of arrangements to a new and less administratively burdensome set of arrangements, the suggestion that we are somehow going to interfere with the work of the Human Rights Commission is ridiculous.

Thirdly, Senator, let me tell you what the principal compliance obligation is, because they will have to have a look at all the complaints that are before them. Let me tell you what the burden which so weighs upon your mind will be. I am advised that the principal burden that will weigh upon the commission is a requirement that they write to each respondent to a complaint that is currently on foot. That is, I am advised, the principal obligation cast upon them—that they write letters to people with whom they are in correspondence already. It is ridiculous, just ridiculous, of you to suggest that that is an unendurable burden for a public agency.

Senator HANSON (Queensland) (12:01): I have been sitting in the chamber listening to the debate on the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill 2017 for the last 2½ hours, nearly three hours, since the chamber started this morning. I have found it very informative. I am not on the government's side. I am one of the crossbenchers, and I am here to listen on behalf of my constituents. I think it has been very informative, and I have learnt a lot this morning. I have listened to both sides' concerns in this chamber.

I would like to say that recommendations have come from the commission itself to the government and changes that need to be done. Through you, Chair, Senator McKim has made a comment about how many cases there are. I do not have the figures in front of me, but I am of the opinion that it is around 124 in this last year. In the previous year it was about 17. That in itself will tell the chamber the number of cases that are coming before the commission. Are they frivolous? Are they just vexatious litigation against innocent people? That is something that needs to be cleaned up, and I think that in changing this legislation with the amendments we will start to head towards that, because the onus is now going to be put on the people making those complaints. They will not be able to just go out there and say, 'I want $250,000.' It is going to be up to the courts to decide that. I think it is a very good step to alleviate the pressure on the commission from people who want to put in frivolous claims.

I will just revert back to the uni students at that time, to the complaint. If anything, it is reverse racism, because here we have some university students who were not Aboriginal who went to use a computer room and found that it was Aboriginal-only. Why shouldn't they put a complaint into the commission themselves, saying that they were wrongly treated? This is what is happening. Where are the opposition, where are the Greens, complaining about this? I do not hear them screaming from the rooftops about this. If you want it to be fair, do it right across the board. Treat everyone equally on an individual needs basis.

I do support the government in these procedural matters changes. I will put it on record. I am sorry that One Nation did not vote with the government in changing the wording regarding insult, offend and humiliate last night—only on the basis that I agree with changing it to 'harass and intimidate'. But it was only on the basis that (2)2B(a) meant that 'harass' was on only one occasion. 'Harass' to me means multiple occasions. That is why I did not support that. I do support that it should have been changed to the two words, as I said.

I wish the opposition and also the Greens would look at this debate in a logical sense and look at what is fair and just. That is all the people ask of us: to look at any legislation in this place and make it fair and just. That is what the people expect of us. The changes in this—I have heard the Greens are going to oppose this. I cannot see any reasonable grounds as to why they are opposing this. It is what the commission has asked for. It is what is fair and just for everyone. It will help us process this whole debate.
Senator LUDLAM (Western Australia—Co-Deputy Leader of the Australian Greens) (12:05): I move:
That the question be now put.

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Senator Ketter ): The question is that the question now be put.
Question agreed to.
The CHAIR: The question is that government amendment (12) on sheet HZ118 be agreed to.

Senator McKIM (Tasmania) (12:12): by leave—I now move to the amendments that have been circulated by the Australian Greens. I will move these amendments in two blocks, with the concurrence of the chamber. I move the first group of amendments (1) to (3) and (7) to (9) on sheet 8119:
(1) Schedule 2, item 29, page 10 (lines 4 and 5), to be opposed.
(2) Schedule 2, item 31, page 10 (lines 8 to 25), to be opposed.
(3) Schedule 2, item 34, page 11 (lines 1 and 2), to be opposed.
(7) Schedule 2, item 52, page 16 (lines 15 and 16), to be opposed.
(8) Schedule 2, items 55 and 56, page 17 (lines 1 to 4), to be opposed.
(9) Schedule 2, item 57, page 17 (lines 5 to 21), to be opposed.

I have spoken about these amendments in my second reading contribution. Can I add that, in procedural terms, I am happy for the questions to be split, if that is the will of the chamber. I would be very happy to do that to facilitate any differences in vote that may exist in terms of the Greens amendments.

Senator JACINTA COLLINS (Victoria) (12:15): I am happy with the approach proposed by Senator McKim. I can indicate, though, that Labor is supporting all of the Greens amendments. I suppose we will wait to hear from the government whether it has any alternative approach that will facilitate that. Let me indicate that Labor is supporting all of these amendments which make appropriate changes to the complaints handling process of the Human Rights Commission. These changes have been made in consultation with the commission in the light of the recommendations of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Human Rights. Labor opposes the introduction of a mandatory 'accept-reject' stage into the commission's complaints process. This will add additional delay and added costs for parties, as the Tasmanian Anti-Discrimination Commissioner has said. This phase would encourage parties to litigate decisions made during the conciliation process of complaints handling.

The commission submitted to the inquiry that proposed section 46PF(9)(a) of the bill should be removed. The obligation to notify a person who is not a respondent but who is the subject of an adverse allegation is likely to be onerous and in many cases unnecessary. It is not needed to address the concerns that have been raised about the commission's handling of the QUT complaint. Those concerns are addressed by Labor's proposed amendments to proposed sections 46PF(7) and 46PF(8) of the bill to implement recommendation 5 of the PJCHR's report.

Labor believes that matters discussed during the conciliation should remain confidential. Proposed sections 46PKA(2) and 46PSA are inconsistent with this, and we will not support them. Privacy and confidentiality are fundamental requirements of the successful operation of the commission's conciliation function and encourage voluntary participation in the process.

Senator BRANDIS (Queensland—Attorney-General, Vice-President of the Executive Council and Leader of the Government in the Senate) (12:15): The government opposes these amendments. The effect of the amendments would be to unwind the main reforms that the Senate has now agreed to. Let us be perfectly clear about that. There are two categories of amendments that have been moved by leave together. The first would be to unwind the decision that the Senate has made to require there to be a mandatory assessment, before an inquiry is commenced, as to whether or not a complaint has substance. That is, in my view, the most important reform we have agreed upon. The effect of Senator McKim's amendments (1), (2) and (3) would be to negative it. For that reason, those amendments should certainly be opposed. Equally, amendments (7), (8) and (9) deal with the costs jurisdiction that we have just discussed and just voted on. Once again, the effect of Senator McKim's amendments would be effectively to negative the decision that the Senate has just made. So all of those senators and particularly crossbench senators who were good enough to support the government's reforms should certainly oppose Senator McKim's amendments because these are a rearguard action to overturn what the Senate has already decided.

Senator McKIM (Tasmania) (12:17): I do not intend to respond at great length to what the Attorney has said, but I do want to place a couple of matters on the record, particularly in relation to—as the Attorney has categorised it—the accept-reject phase for dealing with complaints. I want to just draw the Senate's attention here to the evidence given to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Human Rights by the former Tasmanian Anti-Discrimination Commissioner, Robin Banks—and an excellent Anti-Discrimination Commissioner she was too, I might add. I will just read into the Hansard record what Ms Banks said about a very similar provision in the Tasmanian Anti-Discrimination Act. She said this:

Litigation in a situation where it is often, but not always, the case where the respondent has more financial and other power—and therefore can use the legal process to create delay and to put the complainant to cost and expense, that this process is designed not to have involved, for either party.

The issue here is that the creation of a mandatory accept-reject phase provides an opportunity for a person to take the matter out of the hands of the commission and into the judicial system. In other words, it is a judicially challengeable decision point that the Attorney is seeking to introduce here.

I make the same argument against this that I made in relation to the previous matters, which is that, although all the rhetoric is about speeding up the duration within which the Human Rights Commission deals with matters, the risk here is delay. The risk here is that someone who has enough money to hire themselves a silk or even to hire themselves a lawyer to advise them will now, should our amendments not be accepted by the Senate, have the opportunity, by the Senate's insertion of a legally challengeable decision point into the Human Rights Commission process, to take matters out of the hands of the commission and into the hands of the courts, with significant extra expense and delay a possibility.

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Senator Ketter ): For the benefit of the chamber, and for clarification because of the wording of the question about to be put, those senators who are in favour of the amendments as proposed by Senator McKim would vote no and those who are against those amendments would vote yes.
The CHAIR: The question is that schedule 2, items 29, 34, 52, 55 and 56 stand as printed, and item 31 and 57, as amended, be agreed to.
Senator McKIM (Tasmania) (12:27): by leave—I move Greens amendments (5), (6) and (10) on sheet 8119 together:
(5) Schedule 2, item 49, page 16 (line 5), omit "(1)".
(6) Schedule 2, item 49, page 16 (lines 9 and 10), omit subsection 46PKA(2).
(10) Schedule 2, item 58, page 18 (line 34), omit "amendments made by items 52, 53 and 57 apply", substitute "amendment made by item 53 applies".

I will speak very briefly to amendments (5) and (6). They go to the issue of confidentiality. Under the current legislation, any report provided by the president to a court on a terminated complaint must not set out or describe anything said or done during conciliation. This is important, in the view of the Greens, because the willingness of parties to voluntarily settle differences through conciliation depends in large part on the confidentiality of the process. Our concern is that, if parties fear that their disclosures during a conciliation may be used against them or published outside the process, it is likely that the process will be weakened. I draw the attention of the Senate to the submission by the Human Rights Commission to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Human Rights, which said:
The Commission considers privacy and confidentiality to be a fundamental requirement of the successful operation of its conciliation function.
In regard to amendment (10), this applies to item 58 and is a consequential amendment to the Australian Greens amendments on costs and termination.

Senator BRANDIS (Queensland—Attorney-General, Vice-President of the Executive Council and Leader of the Government in the Senate) (12:28): The government opposes these amendments and it does so because, although Senator McKim did not say so in his contribution, they, in effect, relitigate the discussion we just had about the costs jurisdiction provided for by section 46PSA.

In relation to confidentiality, Senator McKim, I largely agree with you, but that is provided for by section 46PKA(1), which provides—this is in the government's bill, okay?—that evidence of anything said or done by a person in the course of the conciliation of a complaint in accordance with section 46PF is not admissible in any proceedings relating to the alleged acts, omissions or practices. So that is the rule. The rule that you say ought to be the case is the case.

The effect of your amendment, though, Senator McKim, would be to remove an exception to that rule in relation to offers to settle the proceedings, which is the very issue that we debated about 40 minutes ago so as to make section 46PSA operable. If Senator McKim's amendment were to be passed, then it would not be possible for the courts to deal with the costs jurisdiction that this chamber has just agreed to, so this is another attempt at a rearguard action to effectively reverse a decision the Senate has just made.
The CHAIR: The question now is that the amendments (5), (6) and (10) on sheet 8119, as moved by Senator McKim, be agreed to.

Senator JACINTA COLLINS (Victoria) (12:37): I seek leave to amend an error in opposition amendment (4) on sheet 8134. The end of amendment (4) refers to subparagraph (j). It should be subparagraph (i).
Leave granted.
Senator JACINTA COLLINS: by leave—I move opposition amendments (1) to (4) as amended on sheet 8134 together:
(1) Schedule 2, item 36, page 11 (lines 12 to 18), omit subsections 46PF(7) and (8), substitute:

(7) If the President has decided to inquire into a complaint and there is more than one respondent to the complaint, the President must use his or her best endeavours to notify, or ensure and confirm the notification of, each of the respondents at or around the same time.
(2) Schedule 2, item 41, page 12 (lines 15 to 19), omit the item, substitute:
Add:
; (j) the President is satisfied, having regard to all the circumstances, that an inquiry, or the continuation of an inquiry, into the complaint is not warranted.
(3) Schedule 2, item 43, page 13 (lines 1 to 14), omit subsections 46PH(1B) to (1D).
(4) Schedule 2, item 53, page 16 (line 21), at the end of paragraph 46PO(3A)(b), add "or (i)".

These amendments clarify the role of the president in the complaints process. There are some situations where a complainant decides not to proceed with a complaint after receiving initial feedback from the commission and asks that their complaint be withdrawn. In those cases a requirement for notification of respondents would be an additional unnecessary step. These amendments implement recommendation (5) of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Human Rights report and reflect a recommendation of the commission.

These amendments also remove sections 46PH(1B) to 46PH(1D). The commission submitted to the committee that mandatory termination provisions are not appropriate. Mandatory termination provisions would encourage parties to a complaint to engage in a judicial review of a decision to terminate or not terminate on this ground during the complaint-handling process. As has been the case in Tasmania, this would lead to additional delay and added costs for parties to complaints. This amendment ensures that the president can still terminate a complaint on the grounds that he or she is satisfied that the complaint was trivial, vexatious, misconceived or lacking in substance.

Senator BRANDIS (Queensland—Attorney-General, Vice-President of the Executive Council and Leader of the Government in the Senate) (12:39): The government opposes these amendments. We have already had this discussion, and I will not detain the Senate for any length at all. This is, effectively, the same amendment as the Greens' amendment which was just defeated. It is an attempt to unwind the decision that the Senate has just made to deal with complaints handling processes, so as to have a preliminary determination by the President as to whether or not the complaint has substance, and to make that step mandatory, before embarking on a full inquiry. This is, as I say, merely a rearguard action to reverse the decisions that the Senate has already made, and, for that reason, obviously, the government will be opposing the amendments, and those of the crossbench who supported the government's position in the previous debate should, with respect, take the same view.
Senator McKIM (Tasmania) (12:40): The Greens understand what Labor's amendments seek to achieve, and, for the reasons put on the record by Senator Collins, the Greens will support these amendments.

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Senator Ketter ): The question is that amendments (1) to (4) on sheet 8134 be agreed to.
Question negatived.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
Third Reading
Senator BRANDIS (Queensland—Attorney-General, Vice-President of the Executive Council and Leader of the Government in the Senate) (12:42): I move:
That this bill be now read a third time.

In doing so, briefly, may I thank all honourable senators for their contributions. May I, in particular, thank the officers of my department, led by Andrew Walter and Emma Swinbourne, for their contributions; and my own staff, led by Liam Brennan, for their contributions. These are significant and material changes that will improve the operation of Australia's Human Rights Commission, to avoid the abuses and the misuse of the commission that we have seen in the recent past. Might I finally, in closing the debate, say that we, in the government, have all been inspired in this debate by those who have been persecuted through its processes and we are inspired today by the memory of the late Bill Leak.

Senator McKIM (Tasmania) (12:43): I want to speak briefly on the third reading. This bill amends a number of matters associated with how the Human Rights Commission operates. Some, as we have consistently said, we believe are improvements and will result in improved processes in the Human Rights Commission. Some, as we have also said, we think are retrograde and will actually reduce the capacity of the commission to do its job. But we are now required to take the bill, as amended, as a whole, and make a judgement on whether or not we should support it on the third reading. We believe, after careful examination of all of the relevant amendments that, on balance, they do constitute a slight improvement for the Human Rights Commission in the way that it operates and, on that basis, we will not be opposing this bill on the third reading.

But I do want to remind the Senate, and remind anyone watching or listening, that—despite the fact that today's debate has been focused exclusively on machinery provisions that relate to the operations of the Human Rights Commission—the landmark decision that this parliament has made when considering this legislation is actually the decision to retain section 18C of the Racial Discrimination Act in its current form. That is a great victory for multicultural Australia; it is a massive defeat for those who sought to make it easier to be racist in our country. Today the Australian Greens are celebrating with multicultural Australia and those who have stood up for that rich fabric that underpins so much of our everyday life and the lucky life that we lead in this country. We celebrate with them in the knowledge that, for now, section 18C of the Racial Discrimination Act remains unchanged and we rededicate ourselves to make sure that it remains unchanged into the future.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a third time.

subdebateinfo.title: Treasury Laws Amendment (Enterprise Tax Plan) Bill 2016

p.span: Treasury Laws Amendment (Enterprise Tax Plan) Bill 2016
Second Reading
Consideration resumed of the motion:

span.span: this bill be now read a second

p.span: Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Deputy Opposition Whip in the Senate) (12:45): We have just been presented with a very, very long speaking list for this bill. I will observe that it is a speaking list, with one exception—that being myself—comprised of government members and, I think, one member of One Nation. There are 17 people on this list. What it suggests to me is that, after this chamber has been sitting for almost a year since an election was held, the government—which went to that election with a great big tax cut for corporations as the centrepiece of their economic management strategy—have made absolutely no progress in any way in establishing a deal to get support for their proposition. How ridiculous. Having spent days debating the failed human rights changes in this chamber, we are now going to be presented with 17 speakers to filibuster on the centrepiece of the government's budget commitments. How ridiculous.
Senator Kim Carr: What sort of management is that?

Senator McALLISTER: As Senator Carr observes, what sort of management is that? I am going to get out of the way. There are obviously many, many, many people on the government side with a great deal to say about this bill, for which there is presently no agreement about how it is to proceed. I will just let you all get on with it.

Senator BACK (Western Australia) (12:47): What is it that people do not get? What is it about people who have never been in or run or paid up for the management and the establishment and the conduct of a business? What is it they do not get? Investment equals jobs. Investment equals productivity. Investment equals production. It equals improved jobs. It equals higher skilled jobs. For a country that relies so heavily on export, investment encourages export. We are a country of 24 million people—an area that has the population of Greater New York—and yet we live in a country the size of continental America, with the exception of Alaska. Does anybody ever ask themselves: how is it that, per capita, Australia and Australians are so wealthy when you have the population of New York in the land mass of America? It is because of investment. Not one of us would be in this place if it had not been for the forethought and the risk-taking and the investment by people before us. In my own case, I can speak of over 40 years of taking risk, mortgaging a home, shifting states and investing. Why? Because I was encouraged by the climate in this country to invest and in so doing expanded my business activities, and in so doing employed more people, improved profitability, improved export opportunities, enhanced Australia's reputation internationally and, indeed, increased the skill level of people who have worked for me. What is it that we do not get about investment? You hear people talking about overseas investment, about multinational investment. If there had not been overseas investment in 1788 there would be no European settlement in this country. It is absolutely beyond me why people do not understand the value and the benefit of investment.

Why do people invest? One, because they see an opportunity. Two, they measure up the risk to decide whether or not the opportunity is worth exploring. Three, they either have, or can, put a case to a bank and they seek investment to be able to establish that business, to employ people, to expand, to develop the skill sets of those people, and to invest in technology or machinery or whatever the nature of the business is. But one of the biggest issues is the taxation regime attendant upon that company.

In my contribution to the debate on the Treasury Laws Amendment (Enterprise Tax Plan) Bill 2016 I will address the ease and speed with which capital can move around the world, and Senator Whish-Wilson of all people knows the ease and speed with which capital can move around the world. Let me give you the best and most current example I can. When the mining tax was introduced by the Labor Party, prior to its introduction 65 per cent of mining exploration investment by ASX registered companies in Australia was in Australia and 35 per cent was overseas. Within one year—not 10, not 15, not long term—when the risk of a mining tax was attendant upon them, do you know how that changed? It changed from 65 per cent exploration in Australia to 35 per cent—it reversed. In the first year alone, investment by ASX registered companies changed from 65 per cent to 35 per cent.

You ask why Australia cannot retain the high tax level it has? You only have to look at that where else it is possible for Australian companies, let alone multinational companies, to invest their funds. In Singapore, what is the corporate tax rate? It is 17 per cent, and the flying time from my home city of Perth to Singapore is the same as the flying time from Perth across to here—and Senator Smith and I desperately hope it won't be long before we get on such a plane to go home! Five hours!
Opposition senators interjecting—

Senator BACK: Isn't it amazing that people who probably have never, ever invested in a business of their own are yelling out at me because I am trying to outline to this chamber and to the people of Australia where the benefit and the value of investment lies. I will treat these interjections with the disdain they deserve and I will go on to explain to you the level of taxation now in the United Kingdom, a country that is about to leave the EU and a country with which we could well be, once again, increasing our levels of trade back to those prior to the British joining the EU. How would those from Tasmania not remember how that tremendous trade in fruit, particularly including apples, collapsed when the British joined the EU. What is their level of taxation? Twenty-four per cent. We know, for example, that should this Trump administration be successful they will reduce their levels of corporate tax to 20 per cent.
Senator Whish-Wilson: Let's join in a race to the bottom, Chris!

Senator BACK: I find it incredible. A man who himself was so tied up in the world of international finance, who knows very, very well that what companies do when they make money beyond paying tax is reinvest that money into their business, in business opportunities and expansion. Senator Whish-Wilson himself has done that; he is an example of that business success. I am at a loss to understand why his principles have changed the way they have. I am sure the day will come when I am given the opportunity to sample some of the product from his enterprise.

But let me concentrate for a moment on small business in this country—the engine room, as we all know. Over three million workers are employed in small business in Australia, and small business contributes $340 billion to our economy. Why do I want to contrast small business with that of large business? Simply because when you look at stability of employment you need look no further than the global financial crisis. What happened with big business at and following the GFC? They reduced staff numbers considerably—yet small business in this country retained and maintained their level of workforce. As we came out of the global financial crisis, we knew what was going on: as always, the entrepreneurial small business person in a region, in a town, in the city or wherever wanted to invest in increasing that business activity. It is in the DNA of people in business to want to expand that business activity. We know that you need that level of stability in an economy, but you also need a competitive tax rate. Why would you do business in Australia if you could do an equivalent rate of business in Singapore, where you are paying 17 per cent in contrast to paying 30 per cent? It is absolutely important that we create a more level playing field.

I will respond to a comment that Senator Whish-Wilson made, because he and I both know something of the economies of the United States of America. We both know in that jurisdiction there is a federal tax and there is a state tax. In the case of California, where I resided and worked, the rate of state tax was about the same as federal tax. Higher taxes—
Senator Whish-Wilson: Five taxes.

Senator BACK: Five taxes. In the state of Texas, there is no state tax. Yes, they earn their revenue charging higher rates on residential and investment land, but there is no state tax. Have a look at the economy of Texas at the moment in contrast to that of California, where many of the cities and the counties of California are actually either bankrupt or near it. In comparison to the United States, I have mentioned United Kingdom, whose corporate tax rates have gone down from 30 per cent in 2008 to 20 per cent in 2015. Over the period 2008 to 2014, Canada reduced its main corporate rate from an average of 36 to 26 per cent and Singapore, as I have mentioned, have reduced theirs to 17 per cent from 20 per cent.

I want to make some comments about the security of activity and what the multinationals and others—the big end of town—are saying. It was only on Tuesday night of this week that Professor Ian Harper from Deloitte Access Economics at the 50th anniversary of the Minerals Council launched the executive summary of mining and mining equipment and technology services in Australia. I want to put on the record the scale of mining and mining technology in this country because they are new figures which Deloitte Access Economics, using figures from the tax office, the Reserve Bank and others, have calculated. I quote from that report. The total economic contribution of Australia's mining and mining equipment and technology sector in 2015-16 was just under $240 billion, representing 15 per cent of the Australian economy, and it supported a total of 1.139 million FTE jobs, or somewhere around 10 per cent of the Australian workforce.

But let me tell you what Professor Harper and his team have recognised might limit or reduce mining activity in this country. Of course, one of those things which is particularly important is a competitive and fair taxation system. As Professor Harper says in his report, it is important to ensure that Australia's corporate taxation rate and other mining related taxes are stable and competitive relative to other economies and to uphold good economic principles in setting taxation policy, especially in respect of taxing business inputs. He speaks of openness to foreign investment and efficient approaches to regulation. I mention again that there are 1.14 million jobs supported by the mining sector in this country. Do we really want to see that level of investment reduced? Do we really want to see that being exported offshore? As Senator Smith knows only too well, that the entire mining activity of Africa is principally serviced and managed out of Western Australian hard rock mining companies. African leaders who came to CHOGM in 2013 realised in speaking to the then Premier of Western Australia that the entire mining industry in their countries was managed within one kilometre of his office in West Perth. So do not think for one minute that there is not the capacity to move that level of investment elsewhere.

I come secondly to another project related to investment and the importance of taxation, and that is the US$100 billion projects by Chevron—Gorgon, on Barrow Island, offshore of Western Australia, and the Wheatstone Project at Onslow. Let me tell you again that two or three of the Gorgon trains, that being LNG, are already producing and already earning massive amounts of export wealth for this country. And by the end of next year all five trains—three at Gorgon and two at Wheatstone—will be producing. From that project, there will be a ship leaving Western Australia every 40 hours for the next 30 years—subject to us being able to ensure a safe and profitable investment climate.

I will share with the chamber some figures from ACIL Allen Consulting. The prediction is that just those two projects will contribute more than $1 trillion to Australia's GDP, 150,000 FTE jobs and $340 billion to the federal revenue of Australia over at that time—besides the incredible upskilling, besides the exporting also of highly skilled Australian workers who have developed technologies that are so valuable. Once again, I go to the conclusions of the managing director of Chevron Australia, Mr Nigel Hearne. In a speech just last week he said Australia can be the world's best producer and supplier of natural gas and we can lead the world in responsible development, in the provision of reliable and affordable energy, facilitating internationally competitive policy settings.

He also goes on to say that we must have a competitive taxation regime so that there will be continued inflow of capital to this country. We have already seen a decision by BP, a company that has been investing heavily in Australia for close to 100 years—the big BP refinery in Western Australia, as Senator Smith and I well know, provides all of the refined product in the west side of the country—has already made a decision that it is not going to proceed with exploration in the Great Australian Bight. Fortunately, Chevron are so minded, as a result of $100 billion of investment to date, that they are going to proceed with exploration in the bight, which they say could well be a very prospective operation indeed.

I come back to the point I made at the beginning of this contribution: what is it that people do not get about the need to have attractive investment incentives? We want jobs; we want people to invest in jobs; we want people to invest in the skilling of those. You know as well as I do, Madam Deputy President, we have the new exciting Shell Prelude, the largest vessel ever built, completing its construction in Korea and to be placed, I believe, on the Jansz field, offshore from Western Australia. The floating LNG.

We have to continue to encourage investment, but we will not encourage investment if we have a tax rate of 30 per cent when those with whom we compete are already down at 24 per cent or 22 per cent and heading to 20 per cent or, in the case of Singapore, 17 per cent. Why would a company do all of its expansion and all of its development and all of its marketing out of Australia if our tax rates at the corporate level are 30 per cent, when one of the largest fuel industry logistics hubs in the world, in Singapore, charges 17 per cent? I ask people who are opposed to this legislation to think very carefully, because you are limiting the future of jobs for yourselves, for your children, for your grandchildren and for the wellbeing of this country.

Senator SMITH (Western Australia—Deputy Government Whip in the Senate) (13:07): It was a long night last night in the Australian Senate. We did not adjourn until 12 o'clock. Clearly that is taking its toll on some of the opposition senators on the other side. They want you to believe there is somehow some grand conspiracy in the Australian Senate this afternoon, because the speaking list for this debate on the Treasury Laws Amendment (Enterprise Tax Plan) Bill 2016 contains just one Labor senator and many, many government senators.
Senator Gallagher: Yes, because you're filibustering.

Senator SMITH: That says two things, Senator Gallagher. That says that coalition senators understand the benefits of tax reform not just for business but in particular for small business. More importantly, it suggests that Labor has something to hide.

What does Labor have to hide? I will give you a tip: you can quickly rush out to the lobby, find a Daily Telegraph of 28 March—just this week—and you will see what Labor is trying to hide. The absence of Labor speakers on the speaking list says one thing: Labor is trying to hide. What could it be that the Labor Party is trying to hide from senators this afternoon, from those people listening to the broadcast and, indeed, from those people in the gallery? What could it possibly be, Senator Gallagher, Senator Urquhart, that you are trying to hide? They are trying to hide the fact that in the past Labor has not just supported corporate tax reform, but gone on the record and defended it vigorously. And I do not mean the Labor Party of the 1980s, even though they had a better economic record than you were able to manage. I am happy to admit it. I have admitted in other places—indeed, in this Senate chamber—that the Labor Party of the 1980s in the way that it tackled economic reform is a model. It is certainly a model for this Labor Party in 2017.

So what is it that Labor is trying to hide by not having any of its speakers on the speakers list? What is it trying to hide? Is it trying to hide Bill Shorten's comments about the importance of corporate tax reform? Is it trying to hide Chris Bowen's comments about corporate tax reform? Is it trying to hide Anthony Albanese's comments about corporate tax reform? Is it trying to hide, indeed, its own Senate leader's comments about the importance of corporate tax reform?
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator Smith, I remind you to refer to others in the other place by their correct titles.
Senator SMITH: You are quite right. My apologies, Madam Deputy President. Is it trying to hide the comments of former Labor Prime Minister Paul Keating?

Let me share with the Senate this afternoon—let me share with you, Senator O'Sullivan; indeed, let me share with the Australian Greens and Senator Lambie—what it is that Labor is trying to hide by having no-one except Senator McAllister, who gave a two- or three-minute speech. No-one in Labor has the courage to come into this Senate chamber and talk about what they have said previously about corporate tax reform. So let me share with the Australian Senate what the current Leader of the Opposition said in March 2011 about the importance of corporate tax reform, the importance of tax cuts for businesses. He said:
… corporate tax reform helps Australia's private sector grow and it creates jobs right up and down the income ladder.
I know! I cannot believe it either! I am going to repeat it:
… corporate tax reform helps Australia's private sector grow and it creates jobs right up and down the income ladder.

I am happy to say at this particular point in time that, on this issue, I support Bill Shorten's view. Bill Shorten should have the courage to support Malcolm Turnbull's view and Senator O'Sullivan's view and Senator Smith's view.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator Smith, I remind you once again. It is not like you. I know we have had a long night and a long day.

Senator SMITH: It was a long night, and I do feel like I am on a bit of a roll, Deputy President. Let me share with the Australian Senate this afternoon why I think that the Labor shadow Treasury spokesman, Chris Bowen, is also correct. Labor's shadow Treasury spokesman, Mr Bowen, said in July 2013:
… our ambition would be lower company tax rates over time because it does improve our international competitiveness.

So said Labor's current shadow Treasurer, Mr Bowen. And on this issue, today in the Senate, I have to say that I agree with the Labor shadow Treasurer, and he should have the courage to agree with Malcolm Turnbull. Indeed, Labor senators should have the courage to come into the Senate this afternoon and support the government's tax cuts. Do you know why? Because they did previously.
Let me share with you that the Labor shadow spokesman on regional development and transport—I am happy to stand corrected—Mr Anthony Albanese, in June 2010, said:
… there is also the reform of company tax. We on this side of the chamber believe it should be reduced by two per cent.
He said:
… there is also the reform of company tax. We on this side of the chamber believe it should be reduced by two per cent.
So said a very senior Labor shadow minister, Mr Anthony Albanese.
Then of course we have Senator Wong's own comments. The Leader of the Opposition in this very Senate said in March 2012:
… lowering of the company tax rate is good economic policy.
Senator O'Sullivan: That's got to be embarrassing for you now!

Senator SMITH: You are probably thinking to yourself, Senator O'Sullivan: 'How can Senator Smith top that? How can Senator Smith top those four quotes?' This will be the last quote to demonstrate what I think is a very, very important point, and I will come to that in a second. Whatever differences I might have with the Australian Labor Party, there can be no disputing that under the stewardship first of former Prime Minister Bob Hawke and later of Paul Keating, on the issue of economic reform, supported by a coalition in opposition who saw the merits of bipartisanship on many of these issues, Mr Keating, the former Prime Minister, said, in February 1993:
We lowered the company tax rate from 39 per cent to 33, providing Australian industry with a business tax system competitive with any in the world.

So, I start my contribution this afternoon by highlighting what I think is a very, very important point. We have a Labor opposition in the Senate that is trying to suggest that somehow the speakers list, full of government senators, is a grand conspiracy. Rather, it is because the Labor Party cannot own up to its current position, which is to oppose company tax cuts, because it highlights, in stark contrast, its earlier position, which was to support company tax cuts, because they know it is in the national interest. They know it is in the economy's interests. They know it is in the interests of small business as well as medium to larger-size businesses in our country.

We often hear that politicians cannot think long term. Nowhere is that truer than with the Labor Party's opposition to the Turnbull government's Enterprise Tax Plan. The difference between this government and the Labor Party is that we are not short-sighted when it comes to making the tough decisions that will support the long-term interests of Australia. Unlike the Labor Party, we are not scared to support business, especially family-run small businesses. Unlike the Labor Party, we believe that creating a fairer tax system and reducing the tax burden on small and medium businesses increases productivity, creates jobs and strengthens our economy.

This bill represents the most significant reform to Australia's business taxation framework since the introduction of the goods and services tax. It will immediately reduce the company tax rate for over 87,000 Australian businesses with a turnover of up to $10 million, taking that tax rate to 27.5 per cent. It will reduce the company tax rate for all Australian businesses to 25 per cent by 2026-27 and increase the unincorporated tax discount for small businesses from five per cent to 16 per cent by 2026-27. These reforms will assist hardworking Australian small businesses, unlock business investment, drive economic activity and create jobs in our local communities. They will support and provide new opportunities for the regional economies in my home state of Western Australia as it transitions out of the mining boom.

These reforms, importantly, will also enable Australian business to invest more of their earnings in employing more Australians and growing their businesses. This is a benefit for every Australian. Of course, we know that these reforms will also drive investment, allowing us to keep our living standards high and improve wages growth. Most importantly, these reforms will allow Australian businesses to once again be globally competitive. They will encourage business to remain in Australia and will provide an incentive for business to relocate to Australia.

Australia may be a geographic island, but we certainly cannot afford to be an economic one. Nor can we afford to believe that here in Australia investment will simply come because of our stable government and safe investment environment. But unfortunately the facts are these: it is no longer good enough just to be a safe destination. The Australian economy now resides in a new economic paradigm, one where ongoing investment is critical, as it is now one of the key drivers of productivity and future economic growth. It is a new paradigm in which a raft of other nations that were once considered high-risk places to invest are seeing a massive influx of capital—capital that Australia is being deprived of because other nations are looking more attractive. This is why encouraging enterprise must be the driving reform or driving force behind reform to Australia's tax system, especially in the area of company tax.

Australia's company tax rate has remained at 30 per cent for more than 15 years. Over that period many other countries have moved to reduce their rates, and I will explain that point in a moment. Fifteen years ago Australia had the ninth-lowest corporate tax rate amongst the advanced economies, and today only five of the 35 countries in the OECD have a corporate tax rate that is higher than ours. In 2014 Australia's taxation was 4.7 per cent of gross domestic product, while the OECD average was 2.8 per cent. What I am trying to demonstrate is that Australia's company tax rate is much too high by international standards. That hinders international investment and it deprives Australians of important economic growth opportunities and job opportunities in their communities.

A high company tax rate means Australian companies have more difficulty in attracting much-needed capital to invest in their businesses—in their machinery, in their technology and in their workers. A high company tax rate environment means companies are less productive, and it means foreign investors are discouraged from doing business here in Australia. The Turnbull government's 10-year Enterprise Tax Plan begins with tax cuts for small and medium sized companies, most of which we know are family-run businesses, and will eventually lead to a flat tax rate of 25 per cent for all companies. This rate will be consistent with the current— (Quorum formed)

I am tempted to start at the very beginning of my speech again, but I only have six minutes. Let me do it in an abbreviated version before I get on to the more substantive issue. The substantive issue is what, in fact, other nations like Australia are doing—what Canada is doing, what the United Kingdom is doing, what Singapore is doing. Before I get to that, let me quickly recap on why there are still no Labor speakers on the speaking list—it is because they have something to hide—
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Order! Senator Smith, I am sure you are well aware of the standing orders around props. Thank you.

Senator SMITH: That is correct. Props are not allowed. But if you go to the Daily Telegraph newspaper of 28 march you will see a very important page, a very important graphic, because it is headed: 'Do as we say, not as we do'. It carries a big image of Bill Shorten, the Leader of the Opposition, and a big photograph of numerous other leaders of the opposition parties in Australia—people like Mr Albanese, Mr Bowen, Senator Wong and, of course, former Labor Prime Minister Paul Keating. The point that the article is trying to make in the Daily Telegraph is that, once upon a time—actually, not so long ago—the Labor Party in this country supported company tax reform, which is the exact same issue that we are talking about here today.

So let me just talk about why it is important. It is not just important because the government believes this is the way to proceed; it is not just important because people like Senator O'Sullivan, Senator Hume, Senator Smith and, before us, Senator Back think it is important; it is important because what are our competitors doing internationally? They are not sitting around waiting for us to change our corporate tax rate. They have moved already and moved significantly. Let us look at some of those countries. I am going to touch briefly on the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Canada, Singapore and, of course, the United States of America. We know in the case of the United Kingdom that in 2010 the newly-elected government of the United Kingdom, faced with the aftermath of the global financial crisis and a budget deficit of around 10 per cent of GDP, reduced their tax rate from 28 per cent to 20 per cent. They reduced it by eight points and are scheduled to take it to 17 per cent by 2020. Why is that important? What happened as a result of that? Did the sky fall in? No. Did the economy hit the skids? No. I will tell you what happened. Britain's lower tax rates have supported a steady and sustained recovery in business investment, which has increased by nearly 25 per cent in the six years to March 2016 and reduced their budget deficit to around four per cent of GDP. In our country, we often look to the United Kingdom to get a measure of what things might work in a policy setting. On this issue, we can trust the experience of the United Kingdom, and the experience was that, by reducing company tax rates, they saw an improvement in their economy; they saw a better position in their budget recovery program.
Let us look closer to home to Tasmania—
Senator O'Sullivan: That would be wrong.

Senator SMITH: As a Western Australian, I try not to look too much at Tasmania. Apologies to Senator Lambie, who is in the chamber. Let us look across the Tasman to New Zealand. What is New Zealand doing? New Zealand cut its company tax rate from 33 per cent to 28 per cent between 2008 and 2011, while also returning its budget to surplus. They are two examples of not just modest tax cuts; I would argue that these are significant and important corporate tax cuts, which delivered economic and budget benefits. We are being told that somehow the sky is going to fall in.

Let us look at Canada, a little bit further afield, but on many levels an economy very similar to ours. It is very heavily dependent on a natural resource base like our own and particularly like my home state of Western Australia. In Canada, they reduced their corporate tax rate from 36.1 per cent to 26.5 per cent. Singapore, again, closer to home, has reduced its corporate tax rate from 20 per cent to 17 per cent. Importantly, in the United States of America, we know that the election of President Trump is heralding a new corporate tax reform program, and their plan is to bring their current level of 35 per cent corporate tax rate to somewhere closer to 15 per cent.

That brief contribution is about saying: if you do not trust Senator O'Sullivan, if you do not trust Senator Smith and if you do not trust Senator Hume, we get that; that is okay—but look at the international experience. However, there is one Australian people should trust, and it is that one Australian who is given that ultimate responsibility for stewarding our economy. That man—because it is a man at the moment; I think it has always been a man—that person is the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia. People can have their views, but he is a very esteemed individual, who has a great responsibility on their shoulders. His name is Philip Lowe, and, at the opening address of the A50 Forum earlier this year, he urged the Australian government, and I am sure he urged the parliament, to embrace corporate tax reform. In his speech he said:
Like other countries, we face the challenge of responding to this—
international tax competition—
while achieving a balance between recurrent spending and fiscal revenue.

He went on to say that a more competitive business tax environment will encourage higher levels of investment in Australia. Corporate tax rates that are increasingly uncompetitive will make it harder for Australia to continue to attract the necessary investment, especially as our economy transitions from the mining investment boom to broader based economic growth.

In the brief time that is available to me, let me just say this: opposing tax cuts that will help Australian businesses to compete and help Australian businesses to create jobs that will repair the budget is anti-Australian. In this Senate chamber this afternoon, who are those who have an anti-Australian sentiment? Who are those who are standing in the way of jobs growth and in the way of improved future investment? They are the Labor senators on the other side, and they do not have to go too far back into their history to see they had a better record when it came to supporting corporate tax reform.

Senator LAMBIE (Tasmania) (13:30): I do not know if it is just because I am tired, but I tell you what, I am having a big chuckle to myself this afternoon. Here we are talking about budget repair, and you are trying to tell us how other countries are doing it. But I will tell you what other countries are not doing; they are not spending a couple of days, on taxpayers' money, arguing over changing a couple of words when it comes to racial discrimination. And we are supposed to be taking you people over there seriously—please!

Madam Deputy President, I rise to speak on the Treasury Laws Amendment (Enterprise Tax Plan) Bill 2016. The Turnbull government gives us an earbashing day in, day out about the need for company tax cuts. The problem is that no-one has ever proved to me that trickle-down economics works—let alone the fact that 579 corporations in Australia pay no company tax at all. That is right: zilch, zero, nothing, not one red cent. And who loses out?
An honourable senator: The people!

Senator LAMBIE: The people! The Australian people—they are the ones who lose out. Here we have a public health system that is stretched to its limits, less money for those schools in need, and ridiculous situations like those faced by community legal centres where that funding is disappearing before their very eyes, and close to 600 corporations pay no tax—fair go! Where is the Australian way? Fair go! So please do not come in here and lecture us about the need for a better deal for corporate Australia until you fix the rules first.

For example, here is an issue that needs to be fixed and explored. Australia now has an energy crisis on the east coast and there is no doubt that government inaction is to blame. We have the ridiculous scenario where, by 2019, Australia will be the world's largest exporter of LNG while we will not be able to keep the lights on at home. The fact is that we pay more than places like Japan—that is how ridiculous it is—which uses our gas. How do you weigh that one up? What has happened here? We have not only an energy crisis but also, according to you people, a budget crisis—although over the last couple of days I am not quite sure about that—once again due to the government sitting on its hands when leadership is required.
I will refer senators to a story that appeared in The Guardian on Wednesday, 29 March, entitled 'Tax justice advocates urge Senate to push for fair take of oil and gas revenue'. The article says:
Australia is poised to blow another resources boom because the petroleum resource rent tax is not collecting enough revenue …
It goes on to say:
When [Treasurer Scott] Morrison announced a formal review of the PRRT—
by ex-Treasury official Mike Callaghan—
in October last year he warned of a rapid decline in revenues from the tax.
He said PRRT revenues had halved since 2012-13 in Australia, while crude oil excise collections had fallen by more than half.

"There have been no changes to the PRRT since 2012 and we think it is timely that these matters be addressed, and be addressed in time for these matters to be considered in the preparation for next year’s budget," he said at the time …
"… It is important these companies pay their fair share [of tax] when it comes to these issues."
Or there is this one from Bloomberg on 26 March, titled 'Everyone's a loser in Australia's LNG boom'. The report asks:
Why is it that one of the world's top five energy exporters can barely keep the lights on?
So not only do we know; the rest of the world knows too—it is rather embarrassing. The report states:
That's not as much of a contradiction as it sounds.
After all, the interests of a country's energy exporters and its domestic consumers are fundamentally opposed. Exporters want high fuel prices to ensure the best profit margin.
Of course they would; they have shareholders. The report continues:
Households and businesses want cheaper electricity bills.
The LNG debacle provides a good test case of what's gone wrong. Australia is on track to overtake Qatar as the world's biggest exporter of shipped gas by 2019 …

Canberra's revenues from its Petroleum Resource Rent Tax fell 60 percent to their lowest level since 1999 in the year through June 2016, despite a 50 percent increase in gas export volumes. Petroleum tax and royalty revenues per oil-equivalent barrel came to about 4.2 percent of the local price of crude—the lowest share since 1990, and well below the 25-year average of 10.4 percent.

The dip is unlikely to be a blip. Thanks to the way the government allows expenses to be deducted before a project makes a taxable profit, it could be decades before the country starts to receive a better return on its mineral wealth. The vast sums spent building Australia's LNG projects have created a tax shield of carried-forward costs that was worth A$238 billion ($182 billion) in 2016, with the figure rising each year 5 percent faster than the yield on government debt.

The upshot of all this is that, while we become the largest exporter of LNG, domestic industries and consumers are facing skyrocketing energy prices that undermine our economy and our wellbeing and put jobs at risk.

As it stands now, the petroleum resource rent tax, the primary tax on oil and gas production, will collect no revenue from the boom in LNG exports. At the same time, on the same volume, Qatar—this is the big one—currently the world's largest LNG exporter, will generate more than $26 billion in royalties from LNG, not including divided income from state owned companies or corporate income tax from foreign investors. We have done something seriously wrong here in this country. I would be holding my head in shame too—do not look at me, because I tell you what: there is something terribly wrong.

Research by the International Transport Workers' Federation has also shown that the world's other large LNG exporters, Nigeria, Indonesia and Malaysia, all generate more than double the government revenue from oil and gas that Australia does. So much for looking after our own backyard first. It is a typical story, a pattern of behaviour. Other countries have national policies in place to provide low-cost energy to support their local industry and local jobs. I have already told you: if you do not do something about our energy prices, our wages and conditions will pay the price. But our budget is also paying the price because of bad decisions that have been made year after year. You can only sell the farm gate once—I am sure the Nationals understand that. We are giving away our resources to the world's largest oil companies for free while we struggle to keep the lights on. How about that? This is an absolute disgrace and a national tragedy in itself.

Unlike our government, other governments have been smarter. Through state owned companies, they have invested in Australian gas resources. These investments are done in the name of ensuring national energy security in their home countries. For example, one-third of the output of the big CSG to LNG projects in Queensland is owned by foreign governments. Chinese companies, ultimately controlled by the Chinese communist party, own more than 17 per cent.
Senator O'Sullivan interjecting—
Senator LAMBIE: Through the chair—Senator O'Sullivan, they are facts. You cannot argue against the facts.
Senator O'Sullivan: Jacqui, you are economically illiterate.
Senator LAMBIE: They are facts.
Senator O'Sullivan: You are making a fool of yourself.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Order!
Senator LAMBIE: Malaysian and Korean state owned companies are also—
Senator Urquhart: Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I would ask that Senator O'Sullivan withdraw that. That is a reflection on a member of this chamber.

Senator Seselja: On the point of order, it was perhaps a criticism of Senator Lambie from Senator O'Sullivan, but it is not unparliamentary to highlight where people are not understanding the economics of a situation, as Senator O'Sullivan clearly did.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator O'Sullivan, it would be helpful if you withdrew the comment.
Senator O'Sullivan: I am noted for my cooperation. I withdraw.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Thank you, Senator O'Sullivan. I appreciate that.
Senator LAMBIE: I did not know those two were economic experts! I clearly got that very wrong! That is not their background, so it is very interesting.

Of the new offshore LNG projects that will not pay any royalties, 87 per cent are foreign owned. Woodside is the only domestic company, and it is 13 per cent owned by Shell. The big winners in Australia's free gas giveaway are the global oil giants—Chevron, Shell and ExxonMobil. We know that they are very experienced in avoiding other tax payments in Australia and around the world.

We know from our Senate inquiry into corporate tax avoidance which has received widespread media coverage that, in addition, the governments of Kuwait, Japan, Taiwan and Korea also own 7.5 per cent of this offshore LNG. While foreign governments have had the foresight to invest in Australia's natural resources for their own energy security, the Australian government has been missing in action on energy policy.

The government has commissioned a review of the PRRT, and the Australian people will demand changes that end the free ride for multinational oil companies. It is time for the government to collect what is owed to the Australian people for the exploitation of our natural resources. It is time to stop cutting the budget in ways that hurt the people who can least afford it and start collecting from those global oil giants that are robbing us blind. Let's be fair and reasonable and stand up for the people who elected us.

Along with most of my crossbench colleagues, I strongly support the proposal put forward by the Tax Justice Network for Australia to extend a royalty to offshore LNG projects to level the playing field and bring them in line with the rest of the oil and gas industry. It is a simple and fair proposal that will generate at least $1 billion in revenue every year, which would go a long way towards supporting our local schools, hospitals and infrastructure.

It will be difficult to consider any budget proposal from the government that does not end the obscene situation of Australia giving away our gas for free in the face of a domestic energy crisis. It is time for the government to step forward and represent the interests of Australians above the interests of foreign governments and some of the world's largest multinational corporations. We expect to see solutions proposed by the Callaghan review into the PRRT incorporated into the government's budget. Not only does the budget bottom line require it but crossbench senators demand it and the Australian people expect it.

I want to return to the company tax and point out again that the Liberal government has not made the case for it. The Australia Institute think tank released a few points to prove why there is not a case for the company tax. Their points are as follows. Firstly, giving business a $50 billion tax cut means $50 billion less the schools, hospitals and other government services. Secondly, this tax cut means an extra $7.4 billion for the big four banks, which are some of the most profitable banks in the world already. You cannot argue with that. $7.4 billion to the big four banks? You cannot argue with that. The winners are tax avoiders and foreign shareholders because the benefits of the company tax mostly go to foreign shareholders, not to Australian shareholders, due to Australia's dividend imputation system. How about that?
Somebody needs to get up on their economics on the other side.
Senator O'Sullivan: What is it, then?
Senator LAMBIE: The US Treasury is a bigger budget winner—
Senator O'Sullivan: I bet you cannot explain it. Go on.

Senator LAMBIE: I think some people are getting a little tired in here. We would like to get through the day. This is what happens when you filibuster. Could we just get on with it? The next point is:
US Treasury is a bigger Budget winner than everyday Australians.

Due to international tax arrangements, US companies in Australia only pay the difference between the two countries' company tax rates to the US Internal Revenue Service. So when Australia cuts its company tax rate, the US gets an extra $11 billion dollars instead of Australia.
It goes on:
Paying less company tax isn’t going to convince Coles or Woolies to hire more checkout staff … There's no correlation between lower company tax rates, employment, or economic growth.
And I am yet to see the modelling for it.
Honourable senators interjecting—
Senator LAMBIE: It obviously must be hurting them. There must be some truth in the words, because this is the most lively I have seen them all day.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Resume your seat, Senator Lambie.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Order, senators!
Senator Seselja interjecting—
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator Seselja! Senator Lambie has the right to be heard in silence.
Senator LAMBIE: The points continue:

Companies do business in Australia because they want to do business in Australia. Foreign investment isn't depended on the company tax rate. In fact, most of Australia's foreign investment comes from countries with lower tax rates.
Just 15 companies share a third of the benefits of the cut.
Most of these companies are huge players in markets with few competitors … and therefore unlikely to change their hiring practices due to the tax cut.

There are better ways to create jobs and help the economy, like the death tax of 15 per cent on estates, worth more than $5 million; a cap on capital gains tax exemptions for houses worth more than $2 million; and a financial transactions tax, which has already been independently costed and will bring in no less than $10 billion per year. But the Treasurer does not want to speak to me or the experts who have put it forward. That is the problem. He does not even want to look at it. You know why they don't they want to do that? Because—goodness me!—it hits their big voter base, which has all the money. God forbid that their political donations were really hit and they had to strap their boots on and actually go and earn their seats! And that is what is going on here.
Senator O'Sullivan: Clive paid for you to be here. Stolen Chinese money got you here.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Order!

Senator Ludlam: On a point of order, Madam Deputy President: before I start my contribution to this debate, I might ask if you would instruct Senator O'Sullivan to withdraw the comment that Senator Lambie is here because of stolen Chinese money. I am not sure if his voice carried all the way up to the chair, but that is an obscene statement to make about one of his colleagues. He should be made to withdraw that.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator O'Sullivan, I did not hear the comment, but if you did make the comment it would be helpful for you to withdraw that.
Senator O'Sullivan: I do not want to make it difficult, and I will not. I will yield to whatever you want, but that is a matter of public fact.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator O'Sullivan—
Senator O'Sullivan: It has been tested in the courts.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator O'Sullivan, please—
Senator O'Sullivan: I do not want to withdraw the statement of fact.
Senator Hanson-Young: You are a fool!

Senator Seselja: Madam Deputy President, on a point of order: you have been asking members of the opposition to withdraw, and you heard, all of us just heard, that interjection from Senator Hanson-Young. I am not going to repeat it, but she should withdraw it.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator Hanson-Young, I would ask you to withdraw that comment.
Senator Hanson-Young: For the sake of the chamber, I will withdraw saying that Senator O'Sullivan is a fool.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Thank you, Senator Hanson-Young. That does not add to the debate.
Senator Bushby: On a point of order, Madam Deputy President: we heard yesterday from the President that you cannot, in withdrawing an inappropriate comment, repeat it.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Yes, that is correct.
Senator Pratt: On that basis, Senator O'Sullivan also—
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator Pratt, are you seeking to make a point of order?
Senator Pratt: Yes. On that basis, Senator O'Sullivan should also completely withdraw his statement.

The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: I am going to get back to where we started from. Senator O'Sullivan, I did ask you to withdraw. If you would please consider withdrawing the comment, that would be helpful, thank you.
Senator O'Sullivan: I withdraw the comment.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Thank you, Senator O'Sullivan. Senator Hanson-Young, I would also ask you to just withdraw the comment.
Senator Hanson-Young: I withdraw.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Thank you, Senator Hanson-Young. Senator Ludlam, you have the call.
Senator LUDLAM (Western Australia—Co-Deputy Leader of the Australian Greens) (13:50): I move:
That the debate be now adjourned.

Colleagues, there are people in here who have been here for much longer than me but, in the 12 years that I have been working in this building, I have never had to bear witness to a display of towering incompetence like this. We all understand why the government are doing this. This is their signature election initiative. Prime Minister Turnbull ran an utterly mediocre and forgettable election campaign, but, if you were paying any attention at all, you would have noticed that the centrepiece of his campaign was a massive tax cut for corporations—
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator Ludlam, you have moved a motion to adjourn the debate. It is not open to you to continue to speak.
Senator LUDLAM: I would speak to the motion by leave, if I may.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator Ludlam has now sought leave to make a statement. Is leave granted? Leave is not granted.
Senator LUDLAM: The motion is now before the chair.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: The question is that the motion that the debate be adjourned, moved by Senator Ludlam, be agreed to.

body.p:
The Senate divided. [13:55]
(The Deputy President—Senator Lines)

p.span:
Senator SESELJA
( Australian Capital Territory — Assistant Minister for Social Services and Multicultural Affairs ) ( 13:59 ): It is a pleasure to contribute to what is a very, very important debate for this nation, and it is certainly a pleasure to follow the economic lecture we just had from Senator Lambie. I for one was very enlightened. When Senator Lambie said that there is no correlation between lower taxes and more investment and more jobs, I saw the Greens nodding away furiously. I was looking forward to hearing Senator Ludlam's contribution because I was hoping that he might be able to get up and back up in his speech what he backed up with his interjections, which is that there is no correlation between lower company taxes and more jobs, more investment and higher wages. It was interesting. Senator Lambie, of course, quoted the Australia Institute, which is that well-known Greens think tank full of former Greens staffers and some left-wing trade union officials. We should, perhaps, put into some context when the Australia Institute comes up with something that backs what the Labor Party and the Greens are saying. It is no surprise that they would do that.

I will come to some of the people who believe that there is a correlation between lower company tax and more investment, more jobs, higher wages. There is a pretty significant body of evidence to that effect. One of the things we have heard in this argument was reflected a little bit in Senator Lambie's contribution, but we certainly heard it from the Labor Party and others. They put it as a binary choice. They say, 'You want to cut company tax.' In fact, they go further than that. They say, 'You want to have a handout to big business.' That is what they call a company tax cut now: a handout to big business. I want to deal with both elements of that. I will come back to that bit. They would say, 'You could be spending it on hospitals and schools and roads and all of those worthy things. The logic is that it is a handout. That is what the Labor Party and the Greens and others claim. It is the logic that, if you cut that, you have no money for other things. That suggests two things. It suggests two courses of action. One is that it suggests it is the government's money in the first place. That is what it suggests—indeed, I guess the same principle would apply for an income tax cut, if you were making that case—that all of the money that companies and individuals earn is somehow the government's money and the government can choose to allow them to keep some of it. That is the logic that is put out every time they use the term 'handout'. They are saying that it is their money, that it is the government's money. It is not. It needs to be earnt. It needs to be created, just as individuals need to earn money and it is their money, and of course they are forced to give some of their money to the government. Companies, of course, are forced to pay taxes. That is right, but we are enforcing on them a contribution from what they have created and what they have earnt. That is first principles when it comes to company tax and the ideas behind whether it is their money or whether it is the government's money. There are investors in companies, there are shareholders, there are employees, and all of them, in one way or another, share in the wealth.
