When you have companies that make no money, when you have companies that make a loss over a period of time, they go out of business, they employ no-one, they create nothing, and then there is also no corporate tax or any other revenue for governments to spend on really important things, like roads, defence, health, education and all of the other worthy things, which of course governments need to deliver on behalf of their communities. That should be the absolute first thing we say.

This is not a giveaway. This is about trying to reduce the amount of tax that companies pay, starting with small and medium enterprises and moving on to large businesses, so that they can be encouraged to invest more money in their businesses, so they can be encouraged to grow their businesses and so that they can be encouraged to employ more Australians. It is a sad reflection on the modern Labor Party that they have now walked away from that principle which, in their heart of hearts, they all know. We know that they have some knowledge of it, but they refuse to accept that it should now be done.

Before I go to what we have heard from well-known Labor figures on the issue of company tax, I want to address this issue. The criticism they make is it is a giveaway to big business. Firstly, it is not a giveaway. It is allowing companies to hold on to some more of their own money that they have created. Every serious economist, notwithstanding Senator Lambie's contribution, will tell you that it encourages greater investment, encourages more jobs and encourages higher wages. They claim it is a giveaway, but they also claim it is a big business giveaway.

The position that the Labor Party are putting on the record for this piece of legislation is that, if you have revenue or turnover of $2.1 million or more, you are a large business. I do not know how many local businesses members of the Labor Party talk to in their electorates, but to have a turnover of a tick over $2 million does not make you a large business—not by a long shot. But the Labor Party are seeking to deny that businesses of $2½ million, $3 million, $3½ million or $4 million are small businesses, which in my opinion they are. Then as we go to $10 million, $25 million or $50 million we are moving up to medium-sized businesses. The Labor Party are saying they are all large businesses and they should not get a tax cut.

First, they are now denying what they know to be true—that company tax cuts have great benefits for the economy, great benefits for employees and great benefits when it comes to jobs. They are also claiming a local pharmacy, some cafes that are over the $2 million mark and any number of pretty ordinary mum-and-dad businesses with a few employees are now considered large businesses. Of course, with the argument that is being made by the Labor Party now, they are considered the enemy. Any business classified as large—and in Labor Party thinking that means over $2 million—is somehow the enemy. We do not see them as the enemy, be they a small business of $2 million, $2½ million or $5 million, a medium business or a large business, because we see them all making great contributions to our nation. We want our small businesses to become medium businesses and then large businesses, because we want them to employ more people. We want them to invest more in our nation. We want them to innovate, do great things and provide great products and services to our community.

That largely does not come from government. There are certain things that government has to do and there are certain things government should do, but most of our products and services are actually delivered by the private sector. They are delivered by people starting businesses—taking risks, investing money, encouraging other people to invest some of their money and take a risk, and sometimes failing in striving to do that. But many times they come up with great products, great innovation and employ people, starting with a few people and sometimes moving up to hundreds, thousands or in some cases tens of thousands of Australians. That has been a big part of the story of who we are and we should not walk away from that.

It is a sad state of affairs for modern Labor that they have today, and in the last few months in the discussion on this, completely walked away from these principles. There is a reason Paul Keating and Bob Hawke saw electoral success in the Hawke-Keating years. While I certainly did not agree with all of their policies by any stretch, you could look back historically and argue they also had some policy success.
Senator Dastyari: We value your concerns.

Senator SESELJA: That policy success was due to the fact that they had a basic understanding which the Labor Party of Sam Dastyari have now thrown out. The modern Labor Party, led by the Leader of the Opposition, Bill Shorten, have completely abandoned that, even though they know it to be true. Paul Keating said back in 1993, when he was going for re-election:
Over the next three years Labor will place the emphasis where it has to be.
On business and on incentives to invest.
The 'Australian company' is today a much more innovative, dynamic, export-oriented entity than it has ever been.
It will be the engine of growth and the pacemaker of employment.
Paul Keating got it, and that is one of the reasons why he cut company tax.

But you do not have to go back to 1993 and Paul Keating. There have been glimpses of this modern Labor Party acknowledging the truth of this. They have acknowledged why cutting company tax is actually good for workers. As recently as September 2015—so, in Labor's time in opposition, when you would think they would be taking stock of some of the massive failures they had as a government—former professor Andrew Leigh said:

We know the company tax rate is a significant drag on growth, largely because capital is more footloose than labour and so there's potential for us to miss out on high-quality investment if we have too high a company tax rate.

And Andrew Leigh was right. He was right then. He is wrong on a lot of things and he is wrong quite often, but he was right on that. He is part of this economic team which has now said, for some sort of rank political purpose, that it will now abandon this principle. I would say to not just Andrew Leigh but all of the Labor senators in this place and members of the Labor Party frontbench: is this the kind of future you want to create for Australia? Do you really want to see an Australia in five or 10 years time with less and less investment?
Senator Hanson-Young interjecting—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT
( Senator O'Sullivan ): Order! Resume your seat if you want to call out.
Senator Hanson-Young: You, of all people.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Order! Please resume your seat, Senator Seselja. Senator Hanson-Young, you will not reflect on this chair. You are interjecting and you are not in your place.
Senator Dastyari: I am in my place!
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: I know that you find that humorous, but no-one else does. Please do not interject. The speaker will be heard in silence—and do not reflect on the chair.

Senator SESELJA: It is quite disorderly for Senator Hanson-Young to be reflecting on the chair. Thank you for bringing her back into line. Senator Hanson-Young's interjections are all along the lines of: if you cut company tax, you are taking money away from this worthy cause or that worthy cause. Based on that logic—and we heard it before from Senator Lambie, we have heard it from other Greens in the chamber and we have heard it from Labor in this debate—I assume the Labor Party would be pushing to increase company tax. Because, if the rate of company tax really does not have any impact on investment and a tax cut is simply taking money away from other areas and there are no behavioural changes, then the logical thing would be to increase it. Presumably that would be Labor's policy, and of course it would be the Greens' policy, going forward. That would be even more disastrous.

We know that increasing company tax would be a disaster. In fact, if we keep it where it is when all of our competitors drop it, that will be effectively doing the same thing because we are going to see our competitiveness dropping rapidly as we see nations around the world dropping their company tax. You only have to have a look around the world at some of the rates. We have heard about how the United States are now planning on dramatically cutting their rate of company tax. We have seen Canada do it. We have seen the UK do it. We know that Singapore are around the 17 per cent mark, and they have seen it drop in recent years. So all of these advanced economies around the world have a lower rate, including New Zealand, Norway and Spain, and in many cases they have quite different economies. Some of our main competitors' economies are quite like us, like Canada, and some of them have economies that are advanced but have a different base: they have all seen the worth of lowering company tax.

Senator Dastyari does not take much of what goes on in this place very seriously, but I would say to him and others: do you really want a future for your kids where they are going to have much lower job prospects? Julia Gillard said it. Julia Gillard said:
If you are against cutting company tax, you are against economic growth. If you are against economic growth, then you are against jobs.

That is not a bad summation, coming from a Left-of-centre Labor leader. We certainly did not agree with much of Julia Gillard's agenda, but she understood this pretty basic fact. It is very difficult to find any sort of serious economist—you mind to drag out the Australia Institute on this—who would back up Senator Lambie's claim, and now it seems to be the claim of the Greens and Labor, that there is no correlation between cutting company tax and more jobs, more investment and higher wages. Senator Hanson-Young obviously believes that there is no correlation. Senator Lambie believes that, but perhaps that is to be expected. But the Labor Party, the alternate party of government in this nation, is now suggesting that cutting company tax has no benefits, implicitly suggesting that increasing company tax levels—
Opposition senators interjecting—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator Seselja, please resume your seat. Senator Hanson-Young, you know it is disorderly to interject and more particularly it is disorderly to interject when you are not in your chair. You are just ignoring the references from this chair in relation to your behaviour and I suggest you desist. Senator Seselja has the call.

Senator SESELJA: It is the Labor Party now that is walking away from this principle. And what will it mean? I talked about the flight of capital. Chris Bowen understands this, even though he has now walked away from it. This is how irresponsible it is: he is fighting against something he knows to be in Australia's national interest. He absolutely knows it. He talked about our rate of company tax versus the rest of the world and the impacts of that. He said that we do not have to have the lowest corporate tax in the world, and, of course, cutting it over time to 25 per cent certainly will not make it the lowest in the world. He said we do, however, need to be concerned if our company tax rate is on the higher side of the world's advanced economies. The 30 per cent rate was reasonably competitive when it was first introduced, but since then other countries have reduced their rates, so the average across the world's economies is now 24 per cent. He goes on to say that it is a Labor thing to have the ambition of reducing company tax, because it promotes investment, creates jobs and drives growth.

So we, the Senate, now have an opportunity to stand up for some good economic policy that is in the national interest. No serious person in this place or in this debate is not on the record as saying that there are significant benefits to be gained from cutting the company tax rate. Whether it was Julia Gillard or her predecessor in Paul Keating, whether it was Bill Shorten as opposition leader or Chris Bowen or an incredible economist, all agree that there are massive benefits and a significant downside to being uncompetitive. That is what we face if we get this kind of obstructionism. So I again says to the Labor Party that this is not a joke. This is not something that is just a game, as Senator Dastyari might see it. It is actually about whether or not his kids and my kids are able to find reasonable jobs and have the opportunity to see their wages rise, to have good living standards and also to have a thriving private sector that can innovate and deliver some of the great products that makes all of our lives better. Those things do not happen by accident. They happen because of the investment, the hard work and the efforts of thousands and thousands of people. Yes, it does need innovators. Yes, it does need entrepreneurs. Yes, it does need people who are prepared to take risks. Most of us are not massive risk takers, but we need people who are prepared to take risks to create businesses. We need people who are prepared to invest some of their own money. We need people who are prepared to provide products that encourage other people to invest and take some risks so that they can create great thing and along the way they can create jobs and grow our economy and see our living standards and our wages go up. These are serious matters that are before us in the Senate today. It is something that deserves to be supported. This legislation would lay a platform for a growing, prosperous and thriving Australia going forward for decades into the future. I commend it to the Senate.

talker.name: O'Sullivan, Sen Barry (The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT)

p.span: Senator HINCH (Victoria) (14:19): Many government speakers in the Treasury Laws Amendment (Enterprise Tax Plan) Bill 2016 debate have talked about being competitive with the rest of the world. They are right. Australia, at 30 per cent, is way above the OECD average, which is about 24-point-something per cent and, coming into our area here, which is very important for trade: China is 25 per cent, Korea is 24.2 per cent, Thailand is 20 per cent, Singapore is 17 per cent, Hong Kong is 16.5 per cent, the UK is 20 per cent, and the new United States administration is talking about reducing the company tax to about 15 or 20 per cent.

I want to bring it closer to home, back into our region and into Australia itself. Originally I signalled to the government that I would support a reduction in company tax for companies in the $2 million to $10 million area. That was against my personal view, because my personal view is that within 10 years I would like to see company tax in Australia be reduced to 25 per cent for all companies. That will not happen, but I thought the plan put forward by the government at the last election to phase this in over 10 years was a responsible way to go. I thought the $10 million cap to get it started would be a good way to go.

Then I did some more research and realised that here at home some very decent companies in the $10 million to $50 million bracket would be hurt by the fact that we had capped it at $10 million. Going back to my home state of Victoria, which is very pertinent, there is a fifth-generation family company called Furphy—the ones who had the water coolers at Gallipoli—in Shepparton that employs 150 people. It would not get any advantage if we brought the cap in at $10 million. In Gippsland, which is really doing it hard at the moment, GippsAero in Traralgon have 75 people on their staff. They would not get any benefit from putting a cap on at $10 million. So I am more than happy to lift that cap to $50 million. I think that would be a wise way for this Senate to go.

The other point here is that many of us voted to put an amendment in that opposed any cuts to Sunday penalty rates. I voted with the opposition on this; I voted against the government. That will affect the bottom lines of businesses. They will not get any cut; they will not get any reduction. Those companies need relief in tough times. This move will increase employment by encouraging investment in equipment and in development, and presumably that would mean more jobs. The other issue here is that businesses are also facing more expenses coming up—legitimately—because there will be a minimum wage increase, which the workers deserve but that businesses have to pay for. That increase will be somewhere between the $8 that was recommended by the Business Council and the $45 that was asked for at the Press Club by the ACTU boss, Ms McManus.

As I said before, there are increasing pressures on companies and workers, not only in regional Victoria but also in other regional areas of all states of Australia, and that is why there has to be some relief. This is why this will be a very good way to go. Lifting the threshold from $10 million to $50 million will mean that nearly 900,000 small- to medium-sized businesses and companies in this country will be better off. They will get tax cuts. Those 800,000-plus companies employ more than four million workers. I say today: give those companies a break.

Senator HUME (Victoria) (14:23): I rise today to speak in support of the government's Treasury Laws Amendment (Enterprise Tax Plan) Bill 2016. This bill, as we all well know, is a key part of the Turnbull government's reform agenda, which will improve our tax system and drive investment in the Australian economy. The government's enterprise tax plan honours our 2016-17 budget commitments to progressively reduce tax rates for corporate entities over the coming decade. Although not all are being debated today, the elements of the government's tax plan include: an immediate reduction of the corporate tax rate to 27.5 per cent for the 2016-17 financial year for businesses with an aggregated turnover of less than $10 million; a progressive extension of this reduction in the corporate tax rate to all corporate entities, regardless of their size, by 2023-24 financial year; and further progressive reductions in the corporate tax rate to 25 per cent by the 2026-27 financial year. There are also consequential amendments to the dividend imputation scheme to keep franking credits aligned with the changes in the corporate tax rate; a progressive increase in the discount for unincorporated small businesses that is equivalent to the changes in the corporate tax rate; and also an increase in the aggregated turnover threshold for access to the small business tax concessions from $2 million to $10 million.

Today the Senate is asked to consider just the first step of this extensive tax plan and vote to ensure the immediate reduction of the corporate tax rate down to 27.5 per cent for businesses with an aggregated turnover of less than $10 million. This critical reform to Australia's corporate tax rate will ensure that the Australian economy is able to effectively transition from the largest mining investment boom in our history to a stronger and more diverse economy. It is absolutely essential that we reduce the burden of tax on Australian employers. It will improve their cash flow, allow them to reinvest in new equipment and machinery, take on new staff and pay higher wages to their existing employees. The eventual progressive reduction in the corporate tax rate for Australian businesses is a core element of the government's economic reform agenda. By returning the Turnbull government, the Australian people have given the coalition a mandate to implement its election commitments. And we have committed to ensuring that Australia's corporate tax rate remains internationally competitive. If Australia is to remain internationally competitive it is vital that we allow our businesses to compete on an equal footing to companies from overseas tax jurisdictions.

This is a government that supports investment and enterprise in the Australian economy. This is a government that supports investment in the future of Australia's economic prosperity. This is why the government has proposed the Enterprise Tax Plan to ensure the economic success of our nation. I am happy to report that I am not alone in my support for reducing company tax rates, and it is with great fondness that I recall the opposition leader's previous comments of support. In 2011 he said:
Cutting the company income tax rate increases domestic productivity and domestic investment.
Mr Shorten said:
More capital means higher productivity and economic growth, and leads to more jobs and higher wages.
Mr Shorten believes company tax cuts lead to more jobs and higher wages. When he was Minister for Financial Services and Superannuation, he said:
Any student of Australian business and economic history since the mid-1980s knows that part of Australia's success was derived through the reduction in the company tax rate.

I find it very convenient that during his time as Assistant Treasurer the Leader of the Opposition was wholly—and, indeed, vocally—supportive of the cuts to the corporate tax rate, telling us all about the positive effects such a move would have for wage and job growth. Yet now, in opposition, he conveniently touts the current economic situation as cause to oppose corporate tax cuts. It strikes me that the Leader of the Opposition is more beholden to political expediency than to the pursuit of sensible policy outcomes. I feel confident that the opposition leader was at that time merely toeing the line, sticking to his talking points and displaying a fleeting loyalty to the Prime Minister of the day. To now not support a reduction in corporate tax is truly bewildering. I ask the Leader of the Opposition: what has changed?

The government's Enterprise Tax Plan will have a profound effect on our economy, including the creation of more Australian jobs. This legislation will reduce the tax burden for 870,000 incorporated businesses with a turnover of less than $10 million. These businesses currently employ more than 3.4 million Australians, representing over one-quarter of the employed labour force. The government recognises that improving cash flow to Australian businesses will have significant positive consequences to the economy, including the creation of more jobs.

Certified Practising Accountants Australia have also stated that there is clear evidence that a reduction in the corporate tax rate would help promote economic activity, promote jobs and growth, and increase prosperity for Australian workers. CPA Australia said on this subject that reducing the tax burden on businesses lifts productivity and increases both their competitiveness and their capacity to expand, and encourages job creation.

The Business Council of Australia also has pointed out that the benefits of the tax cuts would be widely shared. It said that Australian workers would be the biggest winners—not foreign shareholders; not the banks; not other big businesses. Australian workers will receive around two-thirds of the total gains because higher investment means more jobs and higher wages.

The government's enterprise tax plan will encourage investment. As we transition from the mining boom, it is vital that we give every business the opportunity to invest, to innovate, to grow, and to employ more Australians. We need a tax system that supports enterprise by backing businesses to invest. We need a tax system that puts more money back in the hands of businesses for capital investment.

The economic flow-on consequences of the government's enterprise tax plan are enormous. Higher investment will lead to permanent increases in wages, support for jobs and increased consumption, and will result in higher living standards. The changes are expected to permanently lift the level of GDP by just over one per cent in the long term.

It is also important to note the substantial changes to the previous $2 million threshold for aggregated turnover, for access to small business concessions, to $10 million. As the institute of company affairs noted, an estimated 90,000 to 100,000 businesses will benefit from lifting this turnover threshold.

Importantly, too, such an expansion of the small-business concessions ensures that existing businesses that are near that $2 million threshold are incentivised to grow, as currently they would lose the concessions once they passed that threshold. Indeed, the Henry report—that tax manifesto of the previous Labor government—recommended that small business concessions be extended further as part of a desire to see a more efficient tax system. That was the Henry report.

While those opposite might like to argue the politically expedient point of limiting the tax cuts to businesses that meet the current definition of 'small business'—those with aggregated turnover of less than $2 million—the government is interested in delivering good policy outcomes which will benefit our country. To limit the reduction in company tax to only a small segment of Australia's incorporated businesses would be to stifle the effectiveness of the policy itself and reduce the ability of almost 100,000 additional businesses to invest in and grow their business more. If the Labor Party were genuinely interested in encouraging employment and wages growth, as they say they are, then they would support the government's proposal to reduce the company tax rate for businesses with an aggregated turnover of less than $10 million, not just $2 million.

The government's enterprise tax plan is one that recognises and accounts for the significant proportion of small businesses that are not incorporated. The government's enterprise tax plan acknowledges the 73 per cent of small businesses that choose to operate outside of corporate entities. This plan will ensure that the discounts are extended to those various legal structures, such as partnerships and trusts, through which small businesses are very commonly operated. The plan ensures that the majority of small businesses which are not incorporated are adequately incentivised to reinvest their capital to wage growth and job creation.

To ensure the growth rates that Australia needs, the reduction in the corporate tax rate prescribed in the coalition's enterprise tax plan will not only be limited to small business entities. The government's enterprise tax plan, though initially reducing the tax rate for small businesses only, hopefully progressively returns to a flat corporate tax rate of 25 per cent in the 2026-27 year. This parliament must not be tempted to restrict the corporate tax rate reductions to small business entities only, despite the political appetite to do so from those opposite.

The Business Council of Australia noted that restricting the tax cuts to smaller businesses would mean missing out on the bulk of the investment gains and barely improving our global competitiveness. Political pressure to restrict the tax cuts to small businesses would lock in a two-tier company tax system and provide for perverse incentives for business to inefficiently structure themselves purely for tax purposes. For the Australian economy to be the beneficiary of renewed investment in capital and in growth and to ensure that we successfully transition from the mining investment boom, it is vital that company taxes across the board are reduced.

Today's bill is the first step in the government's enterprise tax plan, which will incentivise all businesses, big and small, to invest in capital, business, jobs and growth. Most importantly, it is vital that Australia act to reform our corporate tax regime in order to ensure ongoing competitiveness in the global marketplace. This is an issue about which we have heard much today. Reform of Australia's company tax rate is critical to maintaining our international competitiveness and ensuring that we are able to incentivise investment in our economy. Only five OECD nations have corporate tax rates higher than Australia—only five. Our tax on business is much higher than our neighbours in our region. Our prohibitively high corporate tax rates act to discourage investment and are a disincentive to enterprises within Australia.

For Australia to maintain the strong and internationally focused economy from which we have for so long been the beneficiary, we must act immediately to ensure that our company tax regime remains internationally competitive. Let us be clear about this: to remain uncompetitive in this space hurts Australian workers. In a modern international economy, capital and labour are highly mobile. Australia's uncompetitive corporate tax rate of 30 per cent compares dismally with the Asian average of 22 per cent and the OECD average of 24 per cent. Businesses, Australian and foreign, are taking their investment, their enterprise, their innovation and their jobs elsewhere.

The Minerals Council of Australia produced a report in which they demonstrate Australia's global tax uncompetitiveness by reference to a range of company tax rates in the industrialised world. I refer to that report now. The Minerals Council states that Australia's 30 per cent tax rate is the 10th highest rate of 43 countries sampled. Australia's rate exceeds the simple average statutory company income tax rates in the G20, which is 28.3 per cent, and the OECD, which is 24.8 per cent. While Australia has not changed its company tax, the average G20 and OECD rates have dropped between one and 1.1 percentage points respectively between 2010 and 2017. So when accounting for all tax provisions related to investment decisions, Australia is in fact the 36th least tax competitive country, which equates to the seventh highest tax burden in the world. We are such a successful economy, and yet we are the seventh highest tax burden in the world.

The MCA also note that, where, on average, OECD nations have been reducing tax burdens on investment, Australia's position has changed very little. In light of this, the reduction in company tax rates will safeguard our international competitiveness and boost investment in Australian businesses. The Minerals Council of Australia repeats the sentiments of the opposition leader: when a country is able to attract more capital, years of income for workers is generated. If the ALP's credentials as a party of the worker are to be believed, they must support this government's initiative to create further employment for Australian workers.

A recent global competitiveness report from the World Economic Forum highlights the higher rates of income and corporate tax rates as the biggest impediment to Australia's international competitiveness. Australia can compete globally in this space, and it is imperative for the future success of our economy that this parliament act now to reduce or corporate tax rate.

It was only earlier this month that President Trump signalled his intention to move on the matter of delivering broad tax cuts in the United States, after suffering the congressional defeat of his healthcare reform agenda. As the president turns his attention to delivering the substantial business tax cuts that he promised during the election, it is vital that Australia does not hamstring its own businesses by preventing them from competing in an international market. There is an element of urgency to these reforms, if Australia is to be allowed to be competitive in globalised international markets.

What is the Labor alternative? I can tell you what the Labor alternative is: there isn't one. Bill Shorten and Labor have rejected the government's enterprise tax plan and want to deny small businesses and their hardworking employees access to further investment and growth opportunities. Mr Shorten consistently claims that we do not need an enterprise tax plan because education will deliver a bigger and more immediate economic benefit. Labor misrepresents the benefits of education over a more competitive tax rate. In the long term education is vitally important, yes, but we need short- to medium-term increases in the private sector. Economic growth will create the jobs for our more highly educated and better trained young Australians. The national accounts show that falling investment continues to be a drag on the economy, and that is why this bill is so desperately important, why we must drop our corporate tax rate as a matter of urgency.

KPMG have also done some modelling on the reduction in the Australian corporate tax rate. Their modelling was of a rate down at 22 per cent. They found that overall, if we dropped our corporate tax rate to 22 per cent, our economy would in fact grow by two per cent. Investment would rise by 3.7 per cent—an enormous amount—and there would be thousands of new jobs created for Australians. This is an extraordinarily powerful indicator of the strength and the efficacy of the government's enterprise tax plan. To put it simply, there is no greater mechanism by which the government can effectively and assuredly set conditions for economic growth in Australia.

We as Australians cannot afford to sit idly on our hands while our international competitiveness is eroded. Inertia is simply no longer an option. Since our nation's birth we have relied on foreign investment. The government's enterprise tax plan will ensure that foreign investment does not bypass Australia and flow to lower-tax jurisdictions in our region. The enterprise tax plan will ensure that the Australian economy is able to compete on the global stage, encouraging investment and enterprise and fostering the growth of Australian jobs and Australian wages.

I implore those opposite to follow their leader's fine example in supporting this reduction in the Australian company tax rate, for those same reasons that he so eloquently articulated during his time as Assistant Treasurer. Can I repeat those comments that he made at the time he was Assistant Treasurer:
Cutting the company income tax rate increases domestic productivity and domestic investment. More capital means higher productivity and economic growth and leads to more jobs and higher wages.
They are Bill Shorten's words, and Chris Bowen backs him up. When he was writing his book Hearts & Minds he said:
… it's a Labor thing to have the ambition of reducing company tax, because it promotes investment, creates jobs and drives growth.
I implore those opposite to follow their leader's example. I commend this bill to the Senate.

Senator FAWCETT (South Australia—Deputy Government Whip in the Senate) (14:43): I also rise to address the Treasury Laws Amendment (Enterprise Tax Plan) Bill 2016, which underpins the Turnbull government's Ten Year Enterprise Tax Plan. What I would like to do is outline briefly some details as to what the plan is but, more importantly, talk about why the plan is important to all sectors of our economy but particularly in the short term to the small business sector. I will talk a little bit about the international experience of tax plans, consider the other views within Australia's political system on tax and, regretfully, come to the conclusion that the opposition of the Labor Party at the moment is purely driven by politics, as opposed to any basis in policy. That stems from their views on this when they were in government.

What the government is seeking to do with this 10-year Enterprise Tax Plan is to look at reducing company tax. I will get to why in a minute, but the aim is, by 10 years, to have reduced that from 30 per cent down to 25 per cent and, for small business, to accelerate their ability to have a lower tax rate.

The important thing is that we will be lifting, for small business, the aggregated income, or turnover, from $2 million to $10 million. What is important to remember is that this is a gross figure; this is not a net figure. Some people would look at that and think, 'Gosh, anyone who's making $2 million a year doesn't deserve a tax break,' but that is turnover. That is not profit. By the time you take out all the costs—operating costs, capital depreciation, stock, wages et cetera—you are not necessarily talking about people who are incredibly well off, but they are the people who employ the majority of Australians. If you look at the employment statistics, small business is the sector that provides the most openings for Australians to get work, so it is a really important sector that we should be supporting. With the lower tax rate if that threshold, that gross aggregated figure, were lifted to $10 million, there would be some 870,000 companies, and that equates to about 3.4 million Australians who would be positively affected by these companies being able to invest more into their business.

Over the 10-year period out to 2026-27, the government would gradually extend that decrease in company tax rate down to 25 per cent for all companies. Bearing in mind that not all small businesses are actually incorporated as companies, the government would extend the unincorporated small-business tax discount in a commensurate manner to encourage those companies.

Why are we doing this? Australia is a small and open economy. Australia's living standards and the quality of the services that we provide rely on our economy growing and the GDP increasing, and that is all linked to trade, to labour productivity, to labour force participation and to population. There is much evidence to indicate that corporate tax rates have a significant influence on each of those factors. Australia's corporate tax rate is high compared to many countries that we compete with for investment, particularly those in the Asia-Pacific region. If we do not attract that investment, then we will not see the opportunities growing.

You only have to read the papers from the last week or two to see a number of companies that have struggled that have received a boost of foreign capital that has enabled them to continue operations, keep their doors open and keep Australians employed—or indeed to grow and expand their operations. There are a number of areas where it is foreign capital that has enabled a start-up in the first place which then provides opportunities for Australians to work.

So ongoing investment is an important feature in terms of productivity growth and jobs growth, which grow our GDP. It is only when that economy grows that we can afford to spend the money we want to spend on the health, the education and the other services that Australians deserve and want to have. But you cannot put the egg in front of the chicken. It actually needs the private sector to be generating that growth in order to be able to fund that in a sustainable manner. On the concept that governments can just keep borrowing or increasing the tax burden, which ultimately falls on individuals, not just companies: there are countless examples domestically and overseas that show that that is not a sustainable model. You need private sector investment and growth if you want your tax base to be sustainable, which is the only way you can sustain the delivery of services and the standard of living that Australians want.

As to the issue of small business and this turnover figure, whilst I currently chair the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, in the last parliament I chaired the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Financial Services. We did an inquiry into bank loans to small business and that gave me the opportunity to interact with a lot of small businesses around the country. When you are talking about a company, and particularly when you are talking about turnovers of millions of dollars, people tend to think of a corporation, being a large company with a headquarters and lots of staff. There are lots of companies in Australia that are run by mum and dad—the bookkeeper is mum and dad at 10 o'clock at night, when they have finally done the day's business, done the homework with the kids, got them into bed, and they can sit down and do the books.

Just because it is only mum and dad does not mean that their turnover is necessarily low. We looked at a range of businesses that came to us and talked about their relationship with banks, we looked into the kind of capital requirements they had to either start up or expand, and we looked at the cash flows that they had. What became very obvious was that the $2 million threshold is well out of date—it does not reflect the reality of business in today's environment. Remember that these are aggregated turnovers; they are not net profits—and there are many companies that are being disadvantaged at the moment and restricted in their ability to grow, and it is not the big end of town. We are often talking about your neighbour up the road who has a company that might just be mum and dad, or they might employ 10 people or 30 people. There are a number of companies in my home state of South Australia that are considered good local companies that employ between 50 and 100 people that should be qualifying for these benefits but even at the $10 million mark some of these would fall outside in terms of gross turnover.

It is really important as we consider this debate to understand that the rhetoric that comes from those opposite that says the government is just giving tax cuts to the big end of town is just not true. In the vast majority of cases we are giving tax cuts to the mums and dads and the family businesses that employ the majority of Australians because it is a fact that has been backed up by both Australian and international experience that lowering the tax rate does encourage business to invest in its people, leading to more jobs and higher productivity, which then helps grow our economy as well as providing a living for more Australians. The concept that small business people are just somehow going to boost their profit incredibly and then all go off and live in mansions somewhere is just not borne out by the facts. The majority of business owners that I spoke to in that inquiry over the past three years highlighted that where they did employ staff the staff were the ones critical to making the business work. If they did not have good staff, the business did not do well. The way that they attracted and retained good staff was to pay, often, above and in some cases well above award conditions. A business that is doing well is almost always a business that is looking to recruit staff and to train them and to retain them, which also means paying them well. There is a cycle there of investment and growth that comes from giving the business that ability to invest in that way.
What is the overseas experience with that? The OECD, which is often used in debates in this place as a reference point in terms of independent but informed thinking about these measures, have said:
Corporate income taxes are the most harmful for growth as they discourage the activities of firms that are the most important for growth: investment in capital and productivity improvements.
Their conclusion is that high rates of corporate tax distort investment decisions and undermine economic growth.

The UK is probably a good exemplar for Australia to look at. According to the UK government, as they look at their recent recovery—and they have had a good recovery; they have seen business investment and jobs growth—they credit as a central part of that the fact that they took the main rate of corporate taxation from 28 per cent down to 20 per cent. That has been a key driver of their economy. Oxford University, in its studies of this whole process, has found that that drove increased business investment by around 11 billion pounds. Importantly, in 2013 the UK government did modelling and published the analysis looking at the long-term economic impacts of these cuts to tax rates—in their case, from 28 down to 20 per cent. What they found is that that could increase the GDP by between 0.6 and 1.3 per cent, which is roughly equivalent with the expectations of cuts here of around one per cent. Again, it is growth in GDP that provides, on a sustainable basis, the ability for governments here in Australia to provide the standard of living and the quality of services that Australians need.

The alternative is to say, 'We're going to increase services, whether through welfare or through other areas, without having regard as to how we're going to pay for it in a sustainable manner.' If you start saying, 'We'll pay for it by increasing company tax rates or not giving them the breaks they need to be able to invest and employ,' over time, perversely, you undermine the ability of the government to sustain those services. If you borrow today to pay for education services, in years to come the children will be saying, 'Fantastic, but there's no work because companies are not investing here and creating the jobs.' I think it is good that under this government we have seen continued growth in funding for health, education and other areas. The rate of growth is not as high as we perhaps would like, but we need to have the commensurate measures that will see Australia's economy grow on a sustainable basis so that we can afford to have the investment in our workforce and the investment, eventually, back into the higher growth rates in those other areas.

Are we alone in this? Obviously not, when you look at the international experience. I just talked about the OECD and Oxford University and the UK government, and we have seen neighbouring countries like Singapore reducing their rates to 17 per cent.

If all of that experience and that informed opinion says it is a good thing to do, members of the Australian public would probably quite reasonably ask the question: why is the opposition not supporting the government's measures in this area? I regret to say that my only conclusion is that it is rank politics. Members opposite are very quick when they are in opposition to play class warfare. Hence their attacks on the Prime Minister about his position and success as a businessman and their constant talk in this place about supporting the big end of town et cetera. But the real question about the validity of the policy, surely, is: what was their position when they were in government. The Leader of the Opposition at the moment, Mr Bill Shorten, was the Assistant Treasurer when Labor were in government. It is worth looking back and asking: when he was in government, what was his view? I quote from Mr Shorten:
Cutting the company income tax rate increases domestic productivity and domestic investment. More capital means higher productivity and economic growth and leads to more jobs and higher wages.
He said that in the parliament in 2011. When he was the Minister for Financial Services and Superannuation, Mr Shorten said on Sky News in March 2012:
Any student of Australian business and economic history since the mid-80s knows part of Australia's success was derived through the reduction in the company tax rate.
We need to be able to make life easier for Australian business, which employs two in every three Australians.

Mr Shorten believed that only couple of years ago when they were in government. But now, when they are in opposition, they are coming out so stridently and not supporting the policy, saying, 'It's just the coalition government supporting the big end of town.' That is a red flag that this is just political opportunism, as opposed to what they really understand to be true in terms of what is good for the economy. It is not just Mr Shorten. Mr Bowen—(Quorum Formed)
Senator Rhiannon: Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek clarification. I thought it was 25 needed in the chamber, and there were 20.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT
( Senator O'Sullivan ): Nineteen is the quorum.

Senator FAWCETT: The numbers in the Senate have not changed pretty much since Federation, or maybe once. The number for a quorum has been a long-established and consistent figure, so perhaps that explains why the Greens cannot be trusted to run the economy. They cannot actually add up a simple number.

span.span: Going back to what I was saying about what the opposition actually believe in terms of policy, I just talked about Mr Shorten and the comments he made as Assistant Treasurer and also when he was the Minister for Financial Services and Superannuation. But also Mr Bowen in his book,

, which he wrote in 2013, had a whole chapter titled 'Promoting growth through cutting company tax'. This is what Mr Bowen said in that chapter, very aptly named in the context of this bill, in his book:

p.span: … Keating knew that the corporate tax rate needed to be cut to make Australia competitive, that capital and investment would flow to tax-competitive nations and that this was an important job-creation move. Today capital is even more mobile than it was then and it is important that our corporate tax rate is competitive.

What we see from members opposite is that when they are in government they also look around the world at the OECD, at nations such as the UK, Singapore and the United States. They see both the economic theory and the practice, and they support, not just in the odd comment but through very deliberate statements—in the case of Mr Bowen, through whole chapters in books that he has written—putting forth on the public record what they really believe about economic theory. And what they really believe is that the government's tax plan is actually the right approach for Australia.

Members of the public who are listening to this debate should not be misled by the rhetoric from those opposite that this government is preferring 'the big end of town' to the Australian worker, because the Labor Party knows—Mr Shorten knows, because he said it himself again and again when he was in government—that the best thing that we can do for Australian workers and Australian families in terms of having a well-paid job and growing our economy so that we can afford the services, the funding for education and health, and the standard of living that we want, is to encourage investment in business here. All of the evidence that we have used to underpin this also underpinned Labor's attitude towards corporate tax rates when they were in government, and it says that lowering tax rates is the best way to support Australian families and Australian workers. So I would encourage the Australian public, as they look at this debate going on, to realise that the rhetoric from the other side is rank political opportunism. Labor sees an opportunity to use class warfare to try to say that the government is out of touch, when in actual fact the government is doing the prudent thing in seeking to encourage investment. As Labor knows, as Labor itself has said, this is the best thing for small business and for big business because it creates more and better paid jobs for everyday Australians.

talker.name: O'Sullivan, Sen Barry (The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT)

p.span: Senator McGRATH (Queensland—Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister) (15:07): Smaller government, lower taxes, greater freedom and the rule of law are not just words; they are the concepts, the values, by which this government is running this country. When we talk about smaller government, that is because we believe that people are the best at making decisions on how they should govern their lives. When it comes to lower taxes, we believe that money is best in a man or woman's pocket rather than being spent by the government. When it comes to greater freedom, we believe that too much freedom is never enough. When it comes to the rule of law, we believe that all should be equal before the law and the law should apply equally to all. This debate today is about this government delivering on a key election promise that we would cut taxes for businesses. Businesses, whether small or large, are the engine room of Australia. They provide the jobs, they provide the money; they are the engine room that drives this country along.

We are in the midst of class warfare at the moment, where business is seen as bad: 'Business does bad things, we must shut business down.' This new leftist anti-business ideology has crept in from the watermelons in the Greens party and has taken over the Labor Party. That is bad for Australia, because business is good. I am proud to stand here and say I love business. I love small business, I love medium business, I love big business. Do you know why? Because they give jobs to people. They allow people to work and earn money in order to look after their families, prosper and grow. But, more importantly—and I will touch upon this later—small business, which I am a particularly big fan of, allows anyone who has a dream to start a business and see that business grow. It is sad that the Senate is trying to block the government from delivering on its key election promise to deliver tax cuts for small businesses, medium businesses and large businesses.

Politicians have a pretty bad reputation and it is probably deserved some times and undeserved at other times, but here is a political party, the Liberal-National Party, which went to an election with a key manifesto pledge that we had a tax enterprise plan and that we would cut taxes for small businesses, for medium businesses and for large businesses. We went to the Australian people and the Australian people said, 'Yes, do it.' In my home state of Queensland, my party—the Liberal-National Party—got 54 per cent of the vote. We got 29 out of 30 seats in Queensland, but what we are being told here is that the Senate is obstructing us in delivering on our promise, and that is very disappointing.

When the four horsemen of the apocalypse come, and surely they will, when judgement day is before us all, we will be divided into two groups. Whether you believe in god or the deity of your choice, we will be divided into two groups: those who believe in freedom and those who do not believe in freedom. Quite frankly, those who do not believe in freedom, I do not really care what happens to you because you deserve to go downstairs. For those of us who believe in freedom—and there actually is freedom of thought, freedom of belief, freedom of speech, freedom of assembly, freedom of religion and the freedom to start a business—we believe that people are the ones who have the best ability to decide in terms of what they should think and what they should say and how they should, and what they can write and whether they should join a union or not join a union, whether they should assemble on the town common and speak and have a protest march or stay at home and watch The Big Bang Theory. It is up to the individual to decide what they do.

Last night, in terms of how we are seeing the new leftist agenda trying to take over Australia—because it is doing so well with Jeremy Corbyn in the UK—the leftists in the Labor Party and the Greens are looking at Jeremy Corbyn and they are licking their lips and saying, 'Yes, we can have a proper left-wing agenda here.' They are looking at the other noted left-wing statesman, Bernie Sanders; they are looking at Venezuela and looking at what we can do by raising taxes, by restricting the freedom of people. We saw that here last night. The two debates we were having here over the last 24 hours were so instructive. The first debate last night was about freedom of speech. The debate today is about the freedom of people to start a business and for us to lower the taxes for those people who want to start a business, because we believe business is good. And then last night we had the gormless gibbons making outrageous allegations because we believe in freedom of speech, because we believe that people have the right to say things, even when we disagree with them. The true test of a society is not the freedoms that you give to people with whom you heartily agree—people you would have at home to have a rum and Coke, sit around outside and smell the frangipanis; it is the rights that you give to the people with whom you passionately disagree.

The problem we face here in Australia is that the political correctness that has overtaken certain political parties and has overtaken certain elements of the media means that certain thoughts, like freedom of speech, are becoming no longer permissible. We have franchised thought, that you can only believe in certain things. If the blob that is the media or the intelligentsia agree with you, you can have those thoughts and they will approve of you having those thoughts and they will heartily agree with you, but, if you utter something with which they disagree, they say, 'We can't have freedom of speech. No, we can't have freedom of speech, thank you very much.' What disappointed me about the debate last night was that it was certainly more than impugned; it was declared that, because we believe in freedom of speech and because we believe that certain people, no matter how much of a bunch of ratbags they are, have the right to say ratbag comments and give ratbags speeches, those on the Left say—I do not want to say it was tortured logic; it was actually outrageous slander—that we must also be racist. The implication was that, because we believe in freedom of speech, we were defending the right of people to speak and therefore we were joining in their disgraceful and disgusting comments.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT
( Senator Marshall ): Senator Farrell, on a point of order.

Senator Farrell: The senator is obviously confused about which piece of legislation we are currently debating. We have dealt with the human rights legislation. We are now dealing with the Treasury laws amendment bill. I wonder if you can direct the senator—
Senator Williams: Don't speak with your mouth full!
Senator McGRATH: on a point of order: he is speaking with his mouth full.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Sit down, Senator McGrath. Senator Farrell, have you finished your point of order?
Senator Farrell: No, I have not.
Senator Williams: No, he's still eating!
Senator Farrell: I wish I was. Could you please direct the senator to the topic, and the topic is the Treasury laws amendment legislation.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: On the point of order, Senator McGrath?

Senator McGRATH: The senator only just came into the chamber. If he had been here from the beginning, he would have followed the debate that I am taking, which is in relation to the freedoms of people to start businesses and operate businesses, and in terms of the attack by leftists on people in Australia at the moment. What we are pushing for here today is allowing people greater freedom by cutting their taxes.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Although you are right that Senator Farrell has not been in the chamber for very long, I have. It is true you had made that point earlier on in your contribution. But I will say that I think, for a fair bit of time, you have been talking about the bill that was dispensed with last night. I would ask you to come back to the bill before us today.

Senator McGRATH: I am suitably admonished, Mr Acting Deputy President Marshall. In terms of businesses and small businesses, it is this side of the chamber who understand business. I do not think anyone on that side of the chamber has actually started a business. I do not think they have actually ever—
Senator Williams: They have finished a lot!

Senator McGRATH: They have finished a lot of businesses. They have turned a lot of large businesses into small businesses, and then sent them bankrupt. But in terms of actually starting a business, well, they did not really go to that class. They sort of skipped that class. They did not attend that lecture.
Senator Williams: They went straight to someone else's business.

Senator McGRATH: They went straight to someone else's business and probably tried to kick the door in, used intimidation to try to join people up to the unions. Remember, this is Bill Shorten, ladies and gentlemen—the Leader of the Opposition who wants to run this country like a union. If that is not the most frightening comment you have ever heard, if that is not the comment that will turn your porridge into yoghurt, I do not know what will. For someone to want to run this country like union—that scares me. It scares me.

We on this side of the chamber understand business. I have beside me Senator O'Sullivan, who has started so many businesses and grown them. In Toowoomba, Barry is known as a very, very successful businessperson. Do you know why he does it? Because he likes to employ people. He likes to give people jobs. Barry is too modest to talk about the things that he has done. But that is what we do on this side of the chamber. My small business career was never as successful as Barry's. When I was about 10, I used to sell custard apples at the gate to our farm at Bli Bli. Then, when I went to Toowoomba, to go to Mount Lofty high school, my sister and I, in the school holidays, set up a company called McGrath Gutter Painters. We went around and painted—Barry, you would understand this—the corners of the gutters when people go into their driveways. Because on this side—
Senator Kim Carr: Is that legal? I do not know if that is legal!
Senator McGRATH: This is typical! Is it legal or not? 'Oh, we have got to get the government in to legislate! We have got to get the government in to regulate!'
Senator Kim Carr interjecting—

Senator McGRATH: 'We have got to get the government's permission to do something! Because the government knows best!' This false deity that the Left worship—the government. 'The government is going to come in, the government will fix everything, and you cannot do anything unless the government gives you permission to do it.' We say the government cannot do anything unless we give the permission to do it.
Senator Kim Carr interjecting—
Senator McGRATH: On this side of the chamber, we understand the trials and tribulations of business. We understand that going into business is tough. We understand that going into—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator O'Sullivan, on a point of order?
Senator O'Sullivan: Senator Carr's interjections are that loud I can hardly hear my own. I am very interested in what Senator McGrath has got to say.
Senator Kim Carr interjecting—
Senator O'Sullivan: I worship the ground he walks on. I want to hear it and I cannot, for the interjections that are coming from the other side.
Senator Kim Carr: It's about the rule of law!
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: I am not sure we should be worshipping the ground other senators walk on in the chamber! However, Senator McGrath, you have the call.

Senator McGRATH: I am very happy to talk about the rule of law. I am very happy to talk about Sally McManus, the head of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and how she believes the rule of law is like a smorgasbord where you go in and choose the bits you like and you throw out the bits that you do not like. That is the chief unionist in Australia. The chief campaigner for the Labor Party is someone who does not believe in the rule of law. Where is the Labor Party condemning her? They are not, because the issue with Sally McManus was not that she told the truth but that she told it publicly. Labor do not believe in the rule of law; that is why they oppose the Australian Building and Construction Commission. (Quorum formed)I believe that Senator Carr asked me about the rule of law, and I am happy to keep talking about the rule of law in terms of how the Australian Council of Trade Unions no longer believe in the rule of law, how they believe that the law can be broken—in fact, they are actually encouraging people to break the law. Doesn't that sum up the modern nature of the Left in Australia, where we have a Labor Party and a Greens party who are happy to be backed by an organisation that do not believe in the rule of law?

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator McGrath, Senator Carr did not ask you any questions, but he did interject. I have given you plenty of opportunity to respond to the interjections, but I think it is now time to come back to the question before the chair.

Senator McGRATH: I am happy to go back to talking about gutters. When I was a spotty-faced 15-year-old, my sister and I were going around the streets of Toowoomba with our own little business, painting gutters. McGrath Gutter Painters never became a multinational. It never went beyond the garage, although my sister and I—hello, Emma—wanted it to. But that is what small business is about. We did not have to—
An honourable senator: It should have been a multinational!

Senator McGRATH: Yes, it should have been a multinational. The issue with small business, or with anyone who starts a small business in their garage—whether it is Henry Ford, before there were garages, or whether it is Mr Jobs and Apple—is that they start their businesses and they want them to grow. They want the small businesses to become medium businesses and they want the medium businesses to become large businesses, because that is what you do in business. The larger your business is, the more people you can employ and the more you can do for your community. What we are trying to do here is to cut taxes, because cutting taxes is a good thing. We should cut more taxes. We should give more money back to businesses. We should give more money back to people so they can use the money to make their own decisions in terms of how they run their lives, not with a government telling them what that money should be spent on.

The debate today clearly shows the dividing line between the sensible side of Australian politics, which just happens to be on this side of the chamber, and the new leftists on that side of the chamber—the Corbynistas, the Bernie Sanderses and the Bill Shortens—who do not believe in business, who do not believe that people should have the right to open a business and grow that business. Those on the Left, when you think about it, want to increase taxes. They want to grow taxes. The only thing the Left want to do in Australia is grow taxes. We want to grow jobs and we want to grow businesses because that is good for the Australian economy. It is the best thing for the Australian economy.

We saw what happened in terms of how Labor treated penalty rates and their reaction to that—remember that, ladies and gentlemen. Remember a guy called—what is his name?—Bill Shorten, the Leader of the Opposition. Labor sent to the Fair Work Commission an inquiry into penalty rates, which was decided upon by Labor appointees on a body that was established by the Labor Party. The body came back with recommendations in relation to penalty rates, and guess what Labor did? They said: 'No, we're not going to accept that. We're not going to accept that because we don't accept the inquiry.' We do not accept that, because you do not understand what it is like to start and operate a small business in Queensland or any part of Australia in terms of the impact that penalty rates can have. What we are seeing here today is that you do not understand the positive impact that cutting taxes will have for small businesses, for medium businesses and for big businesses.

It is interesting how Labor have tried to frame this debate. You have framed it around 'those evil, faceless multinationals and those evil bankers'. But you have not spoken about the small businesses. You have not spoken about the medium businesses. You have not spoken about those businesses which employ millions of Australians. You have not spoken about the work they go through each day and each night, because you do not understand the business world. You do not understand it at all. No-one in the Labor Party and no-one in the Greens—with an honourable exception—really understands what it is like to run a small business and that sometimes, quite often, more often than not, you go without to make sure that you look after your staff, and you go without to make sure that your bills are paid. What we want to do here is make sure that business, which is the engine of Australia—it is what employs people; it is what provides the money to fund our public services—is given a tax cut so it can continue to grow and it can continue to employ people.

It is very interesting to look at who sits on either side of the dispatch box in the other place. We have Malcolm Turnbull and Barnaby Joyce. Barnaby Joyce is a country accountant, someone who started his own practice out at St George. He understands what it is like to run a small business, to start from scratch, to get that shingle and put it out the front of some rented premises and to get some signs and go, 'This is my business.' You know what? It is so exciting starting a business, but it is also completely terrifying because there is always the thought that Labor may win another election, and they will increase taxes, increase red tape and grind business back into the ground because all the Left can think about is that productivity and efficiency and growth come from government. They do not come from government. The best thing about Australia is business. The best thing about Australia is small business especially, because small business provides jobs. (Quorum formed)

I have been speaking about small business and how wonderful small business is for Australia, but do you ever hear a Labor member of parliament talk about small business and how wonderful small business is for Australia? No.
Senator O'Sullivan interjecting—

Senator McGRATH: The Greens? Yes, we will give them a tick there—maybe half a tick or a quarter of a tick—but Labor does not understand business. This is the issue that we face in Australia at the moment. We have had the Labor Party come together as a union reunion, this union blancmange, in the Senate—a retirement home for union hacks as part of some factional deal. They come here and they do not understand how to fill out simple forms, like a business activity statement—if I asked Labor what the letters BAS stood for I know they would say that they don't know and would not understand it. They would get their Google out and try to type the letters in to see what it means.

This is the issue we face here, because we do want to help business. We are being very sincere about this. We took this key pledge to the election as part of our enterprise tax plan—that over 10 years we would cut taxes for business and we would start off with small and medium businesses. We know that Australia is no longer its own little island by itself. We are competing with countries all around the world. When you look at the United Kingdom, their company tax rate is 20 per cent. We look at some of the Asian countries, where they are in the teens. We want to attract investment to this country. We want to attract people here to spend money to help create jobs, but they look at our company tax rate, which is 1970-esque in terms of British tax rates. It is too high and it scares people away. More importantly, we want to cut taxes for small and medium businesses because we understand that that is where millions of Australians work—it is where millions of Australians earn their money to look after their families. It is in the country towns and in the suburbs. When you go down the strip malls and into the large shopping centres and they are small businesses. Whether it is a McDonalds franchise or an independent burger shop, they are small businesses and they employ Australians.

It is our duty to cut taxes for them, because when we cut taxes for them they can grow, they can employ more Australians and they can start up more businesses. I want every small business in Australia not just to be a small business. I want every small business in Australia to become a medium business and I would love every medium business to then become a large business, because who knows where the future Myers is or the future Ford, Google and Facebook are. They probably have not been discovered yet, but if we keep putting up taxes on them it will be harder for them to be discovered. Let us cut tax now.

talker.name: Marshall, Sen Gavin (The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT)

p.span: Senator O'SULLIVAN (Queensland) (15:34): I am really pleased to see my two good friends from the Labor Party come down to listen to my contribution. Senator Sterle had told me that he had to slip out because he had five dollars each way on a horse called Pink Batts in the fifth at Wangaratta. Of course, that is a segue for me to speak about economic attitudes within the Australian Labor Party, or lack thereof. I hope not to reflect on it too seriously. I must make a mental note to ask the whip to never put me on the speaking list after Senator McGrath. What a sterling contribution. It attracted not one but two quorum calls from the Greens. That takes a bit of doing. I got your third one accidentally, but I am going to take that and I am hoping that they dislike me enough to do at least one more and maybe two. You have 20 minutes of me, so sit there, kick your shoes off and have a listen, because I am about to give you people a lesson in basic economics.

The best way to do this is to start right at the beginning. If you have a sharp pencil over there you should pick it up and get yourself a clean piece of paper. We will use only the three numbers. We are not going to put the intellect under any sort of pressure. There are three numbers: one, two and three. Just write them down and follow the script: one plus one equals two and one plus two equals three. They are the simple formulas. They are the only important formulas. I am pleased to see you nod, because the one that you missed and that you people miss all time is one minus three, which leaves minus two, or in your case a $300 billion legacy where you and you and you—through you, I should say, Acting Deputy President, to him, him and him—borrowed, on behalf of the next two generations of Australians, to spend on the administration of this nation on Pink Batts and school halls money this country did not have. How were you able to do that? How were you able to borrow $300 billion? I will tell you how. When they came into the place they went straight to the passbook and whipped it open and what did they see? They saw black ink. That is what they saw. There had not been any red ink, because Prime Minister Howard and Treasurer Costello had laboured away over nine years to whittle away the last debt legacy that they left this nation. Don't go fellas, don't go. Do you want me to pause until you get up to your room and you can watch this on the television? I will get you a copy of the Hansard.
Senator Whish-Wilson interjecting—
Senator O'SULLIVAN: Senator Whish-Wilson, I thought you knew and understood economics.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT
( Senator Marshall ): Senator O'Sullivan, resume your seat. Senator McKim on a point of order?
Senator McKim: I ask that you make a request of Senator O'Sullivan to direct his remarks through the chair.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senators actually address their remarks to the chair, not through the chair, so I will remind senators that they should address their comments to the chair.

Senator O'SULLIVAN: Thank you. I was just being polite. I hate to turn my back on someone when I'm ripping into them! But I will be conscious that I need to do it to the chair. So, Senator McKim, you should probably get up front there and get a seat with your mates in the Labor Party so that I can look at you—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator O'Sullivan, resume your seat. Senator McKim, a point of order.
Senator McKim: Chair, he is addressing his remarks to me, just after you have asked him to direct his remarks to the chair. He is showing clear contempt for your ruling.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator O'Sullivan, maybe you misunderstood me. The comments are directed to me, but I am not fussed as to where you look when you are making those comments. Senator Gallacher, a point of order.
Senator Gallacher: Chair, a point of order under 193(3). I am offended by being accused of being a mate of the Greens!
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator O'Sullivan, you have the call.

Senator O'SULLIVAN: I am happy to withdraw that. It was in respect of my two colleagues over there. I will withdraw it. I understand how you would be offended. But I have said before that you know you are on the money when every 30 seconds they get up and try and pull your speech up.

span.span: A quorum having been called and the bells being rung—

p.span: Honourable senators interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: I remind senators that they should not be discourteous to each other even during the period when the bells are ringing. Senator O'Sullivan, you have the call.

Senator O'SULLIVAN: I do intend to take that interjection that occurred while the quorum was going, because it really goes to the heart of this. A reference was made to me by a senator in here in relation to my personal circumstances. As I have often said, the only family poorer than mine was the family I married into. We had nothing—and I mean 'nothing'. When my wife and I married, at 18 years of age, everything we owned was in the boot of a Cortina. I have been blessed in life. I did not win the pools. I avoided drug dealing. I have been an honest businessmen all my life and I have achieved something. As a result, I know a little bit about economic issues and about business. And I know this—and this is the other note you need to put under the '1, 2, 3': if you spend more money than you make, you are going to go broke, you are going to go belly up.

The difference in what has happened over recent times is that our nation might survive the terrible legacy that was left to it when we had a change of government, but I promise you that the next generation will not. People talk in this place about caring about these people up here, these young men and women—it is men and women; I cannot see that far; yes, it is indeed young men and women. They are the ones who are going to pay for the mistakes that—through you, or at you, Mr Acting Deputy President Marshall—you made before this government received this legacy. Honestly, I said it the other day and I will say it again: if some of you put your hand in your pocket and found a 10-pound note, you would have someone else's pants on.

The Australian Labor Party has made an art form of producing union representatives to come and sit in this place. Some of them are very skilled people. They are very intelligent. Some of them are decent—not all of them but a lot of them are decent people. But all they have done is made a profession of taking something off someone else. That is what they have done. And they have no idea of how a company makes money—none whatsoever.

I want to turn to agriculture, because it is agriculture, it is primary production, it is all of those economies that support my communities of interest, and those of Senator Williams and Senator Back and, indeed, everyone on this side. We do not have any lines on the page. We look after the bush and the city. We look after the provincial. We look after it all the same, not like the Labor Party in my home state. None of their senators have come in here to make a contribution today about the businesses across my state. Do you know why? They are out there on Google, trying to find out what is on at the Gold Coast tomorrow, because that is where they live. They have never seen a kangaroo. They have never had a dent in the fender from a kangaroo, and there is a reason for that. Unless a kangaroo escapes from the golf course down there at Surfers Paradise, those opposite are never going to get within striking distance of it.
