They had one senator up in North Queensland, and what did they do? Choppy, choppy, choppy. She woke up, sat up on the edge of her bed and her head was still on the pillow. That is what the Labor Party does to people who represent people in regional areas.

This issue here is what separates us. Economic management is what separates us. There are so many people who have criticised how, in modern politics, we have gravitated to the middle and how we all look the same. Kevin Rudd, of course, became 'John Howard lite'. Everyone understood what you had to do, but I promise you this: I am excited about the fact that you and the Greens are resisting this legislation, because you have just set us apart. That is what you have done. You have set us apart. There are tens of millions of Australians who can now make a decision. Many of them have for decades—those who are sadly as old I am—known exactly what the Labor Party does. They ruin the economy.

I grew up in a Labor household. I have said it in this place: if my dear departed dad could punch his hand through his coffin lid, he would mark the Labor box, despite who the candidate was. I was a Catholic of the fifties and sixties. I was in a Labor family. I was in a Labor street. I was in a Labor suburb. I was in a Labor parish.
Senator Sterle: What went wrong?
Senator O'SULLIVAN: Listen, don't you talk, mate. You and you are closer to me than you and you are to him, right? No, not him, sorry; but some of the others.
Senator Moore: Her.

Senator O'SULLIVAN: No, I started with him. You do not understand the economy. You do not understand what makes a business tick. Before I came to this place I employed 200 people—and that firm is still going—and then there were probably another 60 or 70 subcontractors and their staff. Do you know how we were able to build that business from nothing, from the back seat of a Cortina? I made money. I generated a profit. I reinvested it in the business. That is what I did. What does 'reinvestment' mean? It means that I bought things for my business. I structured my business. And then I parted with that money to other businesses to do that for me. I bought lumber. I bought tin. I bought concrete. I hired subcontractors to dig holes for me. That is where it went. What did they do with it? They gave it to their employees. This is how the economy works. When I made a few more bob and I cleared the hurdle, I spent it again. I bought more concrete. Then I had to employ more staff to manage the volume of concrete I was buying. That is what I did over a long period of time.

I do not want to reflect on my two friends, and I hope I have not ruined their dual careers as a result of this, but let me say this: I have invited the Labor Party and the Greens to tell me about this before. I asked them to show me one of them who has employed anybody and to show me one of them who has lain awake at night sick in the stomach about how they were going to pay payroll on Monday, how they were going to pay their land tax and how they were going to pay their income tax. They would not know. We had a contribution from Senator Lambie today. I broke out in a cold sweat there for about five minutes! I thought I had been doing it all wrong all these years, because everything she had to say was absolutely opposite to my instincts in business.

I will tell you this: governments can do one of three things around the economy. They can borrow money, and those on the other side deadset know all about that. They can increase taxes and charges, and they also know about that. Or they can cut services, and they know nothing about that because it is in the environment when the other two are absent that they go and really get bolshie. They increase things. They put things in place and do not put them in the forward estimates. For decades, as long as my adult memory can go back, I know that Labor have come into the federal level and they have done some good things over the years—some terrific things—but what they are no good at is managing the economy. They take a drunken soldier approach.

The Greens are antibusiness and they are antidevelopment. They will not be happy until we are naked in a forest with a dead leaf over it and eating tofu made from dead grass! That is it. They think everything else comes from the fairy at the bottom of the garden. They really do. They think the timber floorboards under their feet at home come from the fairy at the bottom of the garden. They think the cotton coats and the cotton trousers they have on—God forbid!—come from the fairy at the bottom of the garden. They know do not know where that comes from. That comes from a plant where we have disturbed the small biology, and we have got some water from the river and we have washed it. and then we have a header—that dirty, filthy header—pumping out a bit of smoke into the atmosphere.

These people would have Australia trust the economy of these nations. This is their history. This is in their blood type. They do not understand the very simple principle of supporting businesses so they can make another small lift in their margin, which I promise you they will do—as I did and as most of them do. They will reinvest it, which generates more activity, more increases in their local economies of interest, more employment and on and on it goes. That circle never ends. That is the principle of business.

I want to go to this business about class warfare that the Labor Party have returned to, tragically, over recent years and referring to these businesses that will be the beneficiaries of this as 'big businesses'. Let me tell you this: it is not hard for a rural business—as you know, Senator Williams—to turn over $4 million or $5 million. That is what it is.
Senator Williams interjecting—

Senator O'SULLIVAN: Yes, including transport companies and graziers. But it is churn. You have only got to go to the figures to see that. They have been around for a long time—nearly 30 years in beef, for a start, where the top end are making about three per cent. Admittedly, in the fullness of time, there is some capital growth in the assets with prudent operators, and that will compensate them in some ways in terms of this small profit margin. But it is about three per cent. I promise you that, by the time these people get through to the end of the year after they have turned over $2 million, $3 million or $4 million, they are lucky to have a taxable income of perhaps $130,000 or $140,000. Do you know how they got that? They got that because mum and dad got up at 4 am, mum and dad did not go to bed until 6 pm or 7 pm and mum and dad did not whinge like some in here did when they had to come and do a fifth day!

Mum and dad never called a quorum on the house, because they did not have the time. They needed to put it into the productivity of their farm. And in fact it was not just the fifth day, Senator McKenzie; it was day 6 and day 7, and when they kneeled down they prayed for rain and an extra day—that is what they did in their lives, to operate their businesses.

And do you know what the kids did when they left boarding school? Did they go to the Gold Coast and bump into a couple of Labor senators? Did they go down to Tasmania—and no reflection on my current friends—where they bumped into a senator every three or four feet in the main street of Hobart? No, they did not. They went home, and they were fencing on the property, they were mustering cattle and they were shearing sheep. They were supporting the Senator Williamses of the world, right?
Senator Hanson-Young: You're frothing at the mouth, Barry—wipe your chin!
Senator McKim: Wipe your chin!

Senator O'SULLIVAN: You see, that is the problem. We can make fun of this, but that is the problem. Here stands someone who knows what it is about; I have been a businessman for 30 years and a politician here for 30 minutes. You do not know, and you scoff and you laugh. Well, you go hard, because the Australian people will watch this; this is one time that they are going to take an interest.

There are millions—I have heard a figure of 3.6 million. But you think of the knock-on effect of those 3.6 million getting a bit more for their labour—businesses making a bit more profit—and going and spending it with another 10 million. I think the knock-on effect is about 7.5. A new dollar makes its way through an economy 7½ times before it expires.
An honourable senator interjecting—
Senator O'SULLIVAN: Well, no. I mean, this is all a lot of fun—and it would be even funnier, if it were not such a serious matter. The only way this country is going to repay—
An honourable senator interjecting—
Senator O'SULLIVAN: No, you have not got, through you—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT
( Senator Marshall ): To me.

Senator O'SULLIVAN: Surely I will receive some award for getting right through it now with doing the right thing. But some of the senators here have not got a clue. They are not worried about the $300 billion debt, because it does not affect them. They have got fat bellies. They will go out and put their bums in a Comcar. They will get to the airport, where their ticket is paid for by the Commonwealth—by these taxpayers who want a tax break. They will go home and roll around in the largesse of their $200,000-a-year salary, none of which they generated themselves—
Senator Hanson-Young: You know all about it, Barry.
Senator O'SULLIVAN: I know enough about you.
Senator Hanson-Young interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Order!

Senator O'SULLIVAN: Mr Acting Deputy President, she needs to speak through the chair. But it is through this illiteracy, at important times, as we try and stimulate our economy—we cannot borrow any more money; nobody wants to cut services; we have tested that in this place time and time and time again—that, when there were $6 billion worth of savings to the economy to repair the structural deficit problem, all of you voted against it.

I am telling you now: when someone is wheeling you around, Senator Hanson-Young—and I really do hope you live a long and full life; long enough for one of your grandkids to ask you—they will ask you: 'Why the hell did you do what you have done? Why the hell did you resist efforts to fix our economy?'
Senator Hanson-Young interjecting—

Senator O'SULLIVAN: See? It is a joke for you. It is a joke. Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President: you have to laugh to conceal your ignorance of the principle of what is being espoused. So I say this: you need to spend some time in understanding the fundamental feature of this legislation. It is to give what I regard as small businesses—perhaps medium, towards the top end—
Senator Hanson-Young interjecting—

Senator O'SULLIVAN: You have not got a clue. Pizza shops turn over up to $8,000 a day, $56,000 a week or $200,000 a month, and there are 12 months in the year; you do the sums—pizza shops, where mum and dad are punching bits of meat on a piece of pastry!

So you again are demonstrating your ignorance, and that is important. I want to continue to promote that, so that the good people of Australia get a chance to make a decision, because they are not as dumb as some. They understand the principles of what this government is trying to do. They will support it. This government will be rewarded. The economy will be rewarded. We will start to fix the structural deficits and, hopefully, just like old Trumpy, we will make this country strong and great again.
Senator Farrell: I think we have to bring this farcical situation to an end. I move:
That the question be now put.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT
( Senator Marshall ): On a point of order, Minister Fifield?

Senator Fifield: While it is open to a senator to rise to their feet and move that particular motion, they cannot do so after they have spoken in the debate. Senator Farrell spoke, offering some comments. A contribution, in whatever form, means that a colleague is not able to move that motion. They have to simply stand up and move that particular motion.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: I might take some advice to get an indication whether the words that Senator Farrell used before in putting that motion do, in fact, constitute a discussion. On advice, I am going to uphold your point of order, Minister Fifield.

p.span: Senator MOORE (Queensland) (16:01): I move:
That the question be now put.
The PRESIDENT: The question is that the motion moved by Senator Moore that the question be now put be agreed to.
The PRESIDENT (16:08): Senator McKim.
Honourable senators interjecting—
The PRESIDENT: Order! Senator McKim, you have the call.
Senator McKIM (Tasmania) (16:08): I will just wait till they regain their composure there, Mr President. It may be some time. Under standing order 201(6), I move:
That the debate be adjourned.
The PRESIDENT: The question is that the debate be now adjourned.

Senator McKENZIE (Victoria) (16:11): I rise to speak on the Treasury Laws Amendment (Enterprise Tax Plan) Bill 2016. I am the daughter of a small business owner. I want to congratulate Senator O'Sullivan for so clearly articulating the reality of living with and growing up in a small business here in Australia. Senator McGrath made a contribution about his attempts with his sister in the small business sphere. He has obviously chosen another path, and he is probably best suited to it. But, still, that sense of entrepreneurialism and creativity and the necessity to have a work ethic which is beyond no other are the core ingredients to be successful in small business.

The reality is that every single dollar and every single hour of my own family was reinvested back into the business for it to grow and for us to be able to employ others. We did not have a lot of employees, but those that we did have were paid well and were seen as an extended part of our family. It was for us to purchase not new cars or palatial holiday homes but a new truck or we would put some money away so that dad could actually pay the power bill.

Small businesses back themselves. They are a unique breed of people who like to start their own enterprises. Small business men and women back themselves, and we as a government back them. We have backed them with our enterprise tax plan. It is a 10-year blueprint, a suite of initiatives to back them to grow and develop. Why would we do that? Why would we bother? Why do we want to make it easier for small to medium enterprises in particular to grow and develop? It is because all the research, evidence and collective personal experience in the sector tells us that small businesses will reinvest in themselves—in their ideas, paddocks, stocks, research and knowledge.

Most importantly, for those of us who care about increasing job opportunities, particularly for young people in this country at this point in time in our nation's growth where the mining boom has come off, it is about ensuring that small businesses can invest in their people. It means employing more people. It means giving existing employees more hours. It means training and upskilling existing staff. I believe that is a very good thing, and I cannot believe some of the contributions I have heard over recent days on this particular initiative, which, as Senator O'Sullivan outlined, completely misunderstands small businesses, how they work and what decreasing the corporate tax rate would deliver for them and how they operate, and the flow-on benefits, not just to the small business owners and operators but, importantly, to our communities, to people looking for a job, people wanting to increase their hours.

We need to ensure that all areas of our economy are supercharged to grow and develop going forward. Small businesses are uniquely positioned across a range of industries to do that. That is why not only are we wanting to implement this suite of initiatives, on which I will go into more detail later, but right across the board our government has been focused on signing new free trade agreements, which give small to medium enterprises priority access into key markets across a range of industries, not just agriculture but education, manufacturing, financial services—a whole suite of opportunities that we have been steadily delivering since the day the coalition government came to power. That is paying significant dividends in our local communities and for me as a senator who represents regional Australia in our regional economies and local areas.

We have the new defence plan. (Quorum formed) Our defence spending is targeted at advanced manufacturing, and that is not occurring just in South Australia, I would like to inform the Senate. There are some fantastic advanced manufacturers, particularly across regional Victoria, who are very excited about the opportunity to contribute to these significant projects within the Defence portfolio and giving them an additional source of income and indeed development of the technical expertise of their employees.

On competition policy, long championed by the Nationals and the Liberal Party, we saw Professor Ian Harper undertake a root and branch examination of competition policy in this country as one of the things our government has been delivering for small business as part of our desire to grow jobs across the country and see small business men and women succeed. The competition policy ensures that those firms with market power are unable now to engage in behaviour that harms the competitive process. Businesses large and small should compete and not be unfairly excluded by their rivals. This has been a significant win, and I know it has been incredibly welcomed by the small business sector. We are very proud to have delivered that.

The industry codes we have been developing over a long time—the horticulture code, the dairy code: those of us who represent particularly the states of Victoria and Tasmania know just how important the dairy industry is to the economic development of our states. Having an industry code that maps out those relationships between producers and processors is important to ensure that there is equity throughout the system. I know we have also announced issues around the sugar code. I know those in Queensland—and I know Senator O'Sullivan has been working in that particular issue for a very long time; for years. He has only been here for a short time, but it was one of the first issues that he took up and championed. (Quorum formed)

I think it is a bit rich for those opposite and, particularly the Australian Greens, to, when it suit them, call for us to have evidence-based policy and, when it suits them, to call to make decisions based in science. But they are very quick to run the other way when it does not suit their particular political persuasion. So here we have all the research in. It is unfortunate. Even the current Leader of the Opposition knows that when you reduce company tax rates more people get jobs. It is the evidence from overseas, and I will go into that in a little more detail later. It is the evidence here. It is the economic theory. Everywhere you look, when you cut corporate tax rates small businesses will reinvest in themselves and will employ more people. It is a simple fact. But they turn their back on the evidence because it does not suit their political narrative at the moment. We know that 1.8 million Australians are looking for extra work to boost their take-home pay at the moment. These tax cuts will assist Australian small businesses to assist with that task—to, maybe, pass on additional hours and, maybe, not employ an additional person but, indeed, offer more hours to those existing employees.

What these tax cuts will be able to do is actually assist in the payment of a significant increase in input costs. I travelled through regional Victoria with the minister for resources recently and spoke to a range of regional small businesses, employing upwards of 60 people in Wangaratta, of 120 people in Wodonga, of close to 300 people in Wahgunyah. To a man and woman, when we spoke about the impact of electricity costs on their business, it is affecting their capacity to grow and develop. It is affecting their capacity to employ more people. When they are telling us their electricity prices are increasing by 30 per cent, you know something is wrong. That is why, with our government backing small business, we have launched an ACCC inquiry to review the electricity market—to ensure that, once again, we are backing small business.

I am really flummoxed, actually, at why those opposite do not understand. They are very happy to bag us out. They want to increase the number of apprentices on work building sites. They want more apprentices, they want more tradies. They are very happy to back that pipeline starting, but what happens when the apprentice graduates and, actually, is a small businessman?

The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator McKenzie, just resume your seat. I am sorry to keep interrupting. I have reminded senators quite a few times today to be in their seats in the chamber. If you wish to have meetings, that is what the lobby is for. I am sorry, Senator McKenzie. Please continue.

Senator McKENZIE: It is no good being an apprentice and earning those wages and doing what you have to do as an apprentice if you do not have the hope that one day you will be a small business. (Quorum formed) It is also why we have initiated the beef inquiry with the ACCC et cetera, because we are backing small business to absolutely ensure that they can get on with doing what they need to do—making sure that our markets are transparent. We are backing those who are trying to make decisions—who are, as Senator O'Sullivan said, getting up at the crack of dawn, looking for more hours in the day to build their business; not taking six weeks holiday and not taking four weeks holiday. As the daughter of a small business man, I was lucky to have two two-week holidays as a family in 15 years because Dad could not afford to take time off from the business or be away from the business for that time.

The reality is that we understand what it means to build and grow a small business, and it is important. We live in a global environment. A lot of my colleagues have gone to the lack of international competitiveness when it comes to Australia's corporate tax rate. We have just heard about President Trump deciding to halve the USA's corporate tax rate, which is a significant shift when we look at our own region where our produce is competing, where many of our small to medium enterprises are seeking to open operations and do business. We are significantly below what the average tax take is; even across the OECD we are in the lowest five of those 35 countries. Something has to be done. You cannot maintain this standard living that we enjoy; governments cannot continue to deliver the level of service that we benefit from in this country and not supercharge those small to medium enterprises which are delivering the dollars to allow you to do that.

I really appreciated Senator Hinch, in his earlier commentary, speaking about two businesses that I have visited in regional Victoria—Furphys down in Shepparton and Gippsland Aeronautics down in Sale, which is around 300 kilometres from Melbourne. Gippsland Aeronautics is an aeronautical business employing significant numbers locally, but what I really appreciate about having this small business in a regional community is that it is showcasing the importance of science and technology to young people within the Gippsland region. It is a high-tech job, as this company supplies aeroplanes to markets such as India and, indeed, a maintenance program. They turn over much closer to $50 million than they $2 million, and that is the reality of it. If we want to supercharge these businesses in our local communities, we cannot assume that we need a level of $2 million. It has to be much, much closer to $50 million, and that is all the evidence before us.
In the Senate Economics Committee's report into this bill, the need for internationally competitive corporate tax settings was raised time and time again:
Research demonstrates cutting company tax will drive capital into Australia for new enterprises, jobs and opportunities.

We need that capital investment, and we need to be internationally competitive to get that flowing here. Other issues raised include the need to address falling levels of business investment and that the Enterprise Tax Plan would incentivise that type of investment. The Enterprise Tax Plan was a driver of growth in the economy, employment and wages. The CPA in Australia argued that there was clear evidence that reducing the tax burden on business lifts productivity, increases both their competitiveness and their capacity to expand and encourages job creation.

Why is the Labor Party, the supposed champion of workers, wanting to stop the creation of jobs? In the face of all the evidence, international and local, when we have the CPA saying it and countless experts and economists saying it, why won't you accept the evidence? You used to base policy in evidence. You used to look at the research. It is just a pity you have turned your back on ensuring that businesses can grow and, therefore, employ more Australians. The report went to outlining some of the benefits. Indeed, Australian Small Business and Family Enterprise Ombudsman, Ms Kate Carnell, made quite a good contribution that I would like to enlighten the Senate about. When we looked at expressing support for increasing the tax discount for unincorporated small businesses, Ms Carnell said that this would account for approximately 73 per cent of small businesses, particularly small family businesses, that choose to manage their affairs through various legal structures such as partnerships and trusts.

This is important for us to actually grow and develop. When we look overseas at the evidence, we see that the UK was able to reduce their corporate tax rate from 28 per cent down to 20 per cent over seven years. Oxford University estimated that that provided an additional 11 billion pounds, which was, again, a significant input into that economy. New Zealand, the UK, Canada—now we know the USA is also considering decreasing their corporate tax rate. We need to address this issue.

As I said, the Labor Party used to look at the evidence and arrive at sometimes different conclusions from those that my side of politics made, but on this they have not. This is a clear case of the Labor Party and the Greens putting raw politics ahead of principle and policy. That is the sad fact of their behaviour when it comes to this bill today. When Bill Shorten was part of government and was tasked with the heavy lifting of ensuring the future job creation for this country occurred, he said:
Cutting the company income tax rate increases domestic productivity and domestic investment. More capital means higher productivity and economic growth and leads to more jobs and higher wages.

If he believed that in 2011, I am not sure we have enough evidence before us to say that something happened between 2011 and 2017 that led him to change his mind. I do not know what that could be other than him becoming opposition leader rather than being the Assistant Treasurer. When he was Minister for Financial Services and Superannuation, he said:

Any student of Australian business and economic history since the mid-80s knows that part of Australia's success was derived through the reduction in the company tax rate … We need to be able to make life easier for Australian business, which employs two in every three Australians.

Mr Shorten said that in 2012. I do not think anything has changed, Mr Shorten. I think you were right then. I think you need to back yourself, Mr Shorten. You need to back the research. You know that this is the right thing to do to get the economy into a place where we can deliver real jobs and real opportunities to so many in our community. Again, when he was Assistant Treasurer:
The Government's tax reform agenda has a strong focus on ensuring that Australia remains an attractive place to invest.
Fantastic! Let's get the capital in. Let's invest. Let's get these jobs going.
This recognises the benefits to investment and growth from lower company tax rates and a trend to lower rates across the OECD over the past 30 years.
You were right, Bill Shorten.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Mr Shorten.
Senator McKENZIE: Mr Bill Shorten, you were right then, and I wish you would back yourself. Back yourself. Chris Bowen wrote in his book Hearts & Minds in 2013:

But Keating knew that the corporate tax rate needed to be cut to make Australia competitive, that capital and investment would flow to tax-competitive nations and that this was an important job-creation move.

So, it is all good and well to sit on the other side and harp on about the unemployed and worry about those people that do not have jobs and worry about those people that do not have enough hours to work—the 1.8 million. It is an absolute farce because, when you have the opportunity to vote on legislation that will make a material and real difference to job creation in this country, you choose to play cheap political games. You choose to play cheap political games instead of backing our small-business community, backing those businesses who are working night and day, with their staff, to grow, develop and contribute. We choose to back them. We choose to back every single one of them.

This legislation will mean a lower tax rate for more than 870,000 companies, employing 3.4 million Australians. That is not just a number; they are actual people taking real wages home. We back Australia's small businesses. We wish the Senate would help us.

Senator BRANDIS (Queensland—Attorney-General, Vice-President of the Executive Council and Leader of the Government in the Senate) (16:35): We have seen a day in which there has been artificial prolongation of the sittings and an extraordinary amount of time wasting on the part of the opposition and, in particular, on the part of the Greens earlier in the day in the consideration of the human rights legislation. I thought I might take a few moments to reflect upon the important work that the Senate has done in this sitting—more of which could have been done, by the way, had the opposition and the Greens not wasted so much of the chamber's time during the course, in particular, of this morning. Let me run through many of the achievements of the government and many of the achievements of this chamber during the course of this sitting. In no particular order, because all of these matters are important, we have achieved more affordable— (Quorum formed)Among other things, what the government has delivered in recent weeks is the funding of more affordable child care, giving around one million Australian families relief from out-of-pocket childcare cost pressures.
Senator Birmingham: Hear, hear!

Senator BRANDIS: I see that Senator Birmingham has joined us in the chamber. A great credit—through you, Madam Deputy President, if I may say so—to you, Senator Birmingham. When the coalition was elected in 2013, we found this sector in a mess. We have attempted, through the course of 3½ years, to sort out—
Senator Dastyari: A point of order as to relevance: the Attorney-General is not even trying to be relevant to the bill anymore.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: It is a wide-ranging debate, and I think Senator Brandis is entitled to make those comments.

Senator BRANDIS: Senator Birmingham, a great credit to you in eventually cutting this Gordian knot, providing around a million Australian families with relief from out-of-pocket childcare cost pressures and providing more children with the opportunity to benefit from an early education. This is the biggest reform to the early education sector for 40 years, and the largest ever boost to the sector. There are many other achievements that this government and this Senate have been able to accomplish in the past several weeks. I want to thank in particular the crossbenchers who have cooperated with the government in delivering those outcomes on this last sitting day of the autumn sittings. I particularly want to pay credit to the crossbenchers who have worked with the government to achieve these outcomes for Australia.

Senator CORMANN (Western Australia—Minister for Finance and Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate) (16:40): I would like to thank all senators who have contributed to this very important debate about a more competitive business tax system for Australia, which was designed by the government to boost investment, boost productivity, generate stronger growth and, of course, create more jobs and, over time, increase real wages. This bill represents the most significant reform to Australia's business taxation framework in a generation. It is a visionary piece of legislation that will help set up Australia for the next decades. It will foster much needed investment and wage growth and will allow businesses to create new jobs. It will solidify Australia as a competitive, pro-business, pro-investment destination.

I would like to thank all of the non-government senators who have been good enough to engage constructively and positively with the government in helping us implement as much of our national economic plan and as much of the agenda that we took to the last election as possible. Of course, we understand that we do not have a majority in this chamber in our own right and we understand that we have to work with non-government senators and that we need to persuade a number of non-government senators in order to be able to successfully pass legislation through the Senate.

In this context and in the context of the government's commitment to pursue a 10-year enterprise tax plan, I would like to personally thank Senators Leyonhjelm and Bernardi who were enthusiastic supporters of lower and more competitive business taxes right from the word go and have indicated to the government that they would be prepared to support the government's enterprise tax plan in full.

Next, I would like to thank the senators from One Nation, who have also engaged constructively with the government and have indicated to us that they would be in a position to support enterprise tax cuts for businesses with a turnover of up to $50 million per annum. That, of course, would help us implement the first three years of our enterprise tax plan with a turnover threshold of $10 million scheduled in our plan for 2016-17, $25 million for 2017-18 and $50 million for the next financial year.

Senator Hinch has also very constructively engaged with the government. I am sure that Senator Hinch will not mind me saying that he was particularly persuaded by the quality of the businesses in Victoria—in particular, across regional Victoria—that would benefit and the workers in those businesses across Victoria that would benefit from a more competitive business tax rate. Of course, by increasing the threshold over the next few years from a turnover threshold of $10 million to a turnover threshold of $50 million, another 10,000 businesses and another one million workers across Australia will benefit from the reduced corporate tax rate that the government is pursuing through this chamber. The government is very grateful for the work that Senator Hinch has done with the government in that regard.

The Nick Xenophon Team, led by Senator Xenophon, engaged with the government in relation to this matter for some time. Both the Nick Xenophon Team and the government are focused on making sure that we have both economic policy and energy policy settings in place that help ensure that our economy is as competitive internationally as possible.

The government has, of course, been indicating for some time that we want to secure the passage of as much of our corporate tax cuts through the Senate as possible. What the government will be proceeding with today, and what we believe we have been able to reach a consensus on across this chamber, is a company tax cut for businesses with a turnover of up to $50 million per year.

Many businesses across Australia and their employees will benefit from the increased investment, the increased job security and the increased opportunity for more jobs and higher wages that will come with legislating this part of our plan today.

We have indicated this to the Nick Xenophon Team and to others in this chamber, and indeed we have been making public announcements in relation to this for some time. The government is very concerned about the issues of affordability and reliability of our energy systems and supply. We are very conscious and very mindful of the need to encourage our markets to work effectively and attract more investment.

I am pleased to inform the chamber—and, through the chamber, people who might be listening to us—that we have been able to reach an agreement to secure passage of the enterprise tax plan, modified as per the above, on the following basis. The government has agreed to explore and pursue a power affordability and reliability policy by directing the AEMC and the Climate Change Authority over the next fortnight to jointly produce a report that provides advice—
Senator Dastyari: He got a report! He got a report!
The PRESIDENT: On my left!
Senator CORMANN: with regard to a policy, or policies, to enhance power system security and to reduce energy prices consistent with achieving our emissions reduction targets in the Paris agreement.
Opposition senators interjecting—

Senator CORMANN: You might want to listen. The report will be informed by independent modelling to be jointly commissioned by the AEMC and the Climate Change Authority and will be factored into the work undertaken by Chief Scientist Finkel on behalf of the Council of Australian Governments. The report will be presented to government by 1 June 2017, made public by 15 June 2017, tabled in parliament on the next available sitting day and taken into account by the government as it acts on the Finkel review recommendations to improve the affordability and reliability of energy supplies.

The government's commitment is, in light of the reports and reviews referred to, to pursue the implementation of a power affordability and reliability policy that can be demonstrated to put downward pressure on electricity prices and enhance energy reliability through relevant changes to the national electricity market rules. The implementation of such a policy would begin at the earliest possible opportunity and no later than 1 July 2018.

We have also reached agreements in relation to gas retention lease arrangements. The government is committed to initiating a national review through the Council of Australian Governments Energy Council of the management and the effectiveness of policies in relation to undeveloped gas titles retained by companies. The government will advance and pursue the introduction of a nationally consistent, stricter use it or lose it test in order to help address the barriers to the commercial development of gas fields.

In relation to gas supply and a public interest test, the government is committed to enforcing the public interest in relation to domestic gas supply by ensuring that the three current east coast LNG projects, and any future eastern market energy projects, are providing additional gas supply into the domestic market, increasing supply into that market. As the Senate would know, the Prime Minister recently met with gas producers to, in the first instance, secure voluntary undertakings to that effect. In the absence of a satisfactory agreement with gas producers by 1 July 2017, the government will protect the public interest by intervening in the gas export markets with the objective of increasing the domestic supply of gas. Further, in the absence of a satisfactory agreement with gas producers, the government will enshrine this arrangement in an ongoing public interest requirement, having regard to, amongst other things, the affordable, reliable, efficient and long-term domestic supply to Australian energy consumers.

The government has also agreed to initiate and announce a Productivity Commission inquiry into the relevant joint marketing arrangements, as recommended by the ACCC in its 2016 inquiry, after the current ACCC inquiry—
Opposition senators interjecting—
The PRESIDENT: On my left! Order!
Senator CORMANN: into the GBJV currently underway has reported—
The PRESIDENT: Senator Hinch, a point of order?
Senator Hinch: On a point of order, Mr President: I am getting tired of not being able to hear the speaker over the Greens' continual stream of interjections.
The PRESIDENT: Thank you, Senator Hinch. Senators, and in particular those on my left at the moment—
Senator Dastyari interjecting—
The PRESIDENT: Senator Dastyari, that applies to you too. Could you please not interject and allow the minister to continue in silence. Minister.
Senator CORMANN: The government has agreed to implement relevant recommendations made by the ACCC and Dr Michael Vertigan AC review to improve price transparency in the gas market.

Further, in the lead-up to the last election, the coalition made a commitment to deliver a solar thermal plant in Port Augusta. The government have agreed, as a result of our discussions with the Nick Xenophon Team, to accelerate and secure delivery of this solar thermal or other large-scale solar project in Port Augusta through a formal call for proposals through the Australian Renewable Energy Agency and the Clean Energy Finance Corporation and by making a Commonwealth concessional loan of up to $110 million available at a three per cent interest rate, which is the bond rate plus one per cent.

Also, the Nick Xenophon Team has raised with us the proposal of a gas pipeline from a location in the Northern Territory to Moomba, in South Australia, as a means of increasing the supply of gas into the south-eastern gas market and the National Electricity Market more generally. There are some relevant proposals that have previously been assessed by the private sector but have not so far been progressed. The government is prepared to help accelerate consideration of this proposal by conducting a national interest and economic cost-benefit analysis as a precursor to a fully-fledged feasibility study. The government's preference would be for a private proponent to develop this project. However, subject to a positive national interest and economic assessment, the government would be prepared to invest in this infrastructure to make it happen. Self-evidently, to strengthen the national interest and economic case for this project, we will need the Northern Territory government to lift its current moratorium on further gas development.

Finally, the government has also agreed, in order to facilitate passage of this legislation in its amended form, to announce a one-off payment of $75 for single recipients and $125 for couple recipients of the age pension, the disability pension and the parenting payment to help them cover the cost of increased electricity prices pending these reforms having the desired effect of bringing down electricity prices and improving energy affordability.

I am very pleased to report to the Senate that, after a lot of good and effective work, constructive work, by crossbenchers in this Senate, the government believe that we have been able to achieve a consensus across this chamber to reduce company tax to 25 per cent for every business with a turnover of up to $50 million over the next three years. This, of course, delivers in full on the commitments we took to the last election for this term of parliament. It will be, of course, a matter for the Australian people to determine at the next election whether they want to see the coalition continue to implement our plan for jobs and growth, our plan for a stronger economy, our plan to help people across Australia to get ahead by continuing to help businesses across Australia to be the most successful they can be.

The one thing that people on this side of the chamber and all of the crossbench senators who have engaged with us understand is that, for individual Australians to be as successful as possible, for individual Australians to have the best possible opportunity to get ahead, we need the businesses that employ them to have the best possible opportunity to be successful and profitable. Letting businesses keep a little bit more of their money to reinvest in their future success will help them hire more Australians and pay them better wages over time. That is what this reform is all about. I thank all those senators who have joined with the government to help make this happen, to help us implement the first three years of our 10-year plan. I commend the bill to the Senate.
The PRESIDENT: The question is that the bill be now read a second time.

body.p:
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

The effect of the government's amendments is that, as I indicated in my summing up speech, instead of applying to all businesses, the company tax cuts will only apply to businesses with a turnover of up to $50 million from the 2018-19 financial year onwards. In 2016-17, it will be $10 million turnover; in 2017-18, it will be $25 million turnover; and, in 2018-19, it will be $50 million turnover. The tax rate will progressively reduce, as per the trajectory in the budget, to 25 per cent. I commend the amendments to the Senate.

Senator GALLAGHER (Australian Capital Territory—Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate) (17:04): Well, what a sitting week it has been, hey? And here we get to the crux of the matter, finally, as we head past five o'clock on a Friday afternoon, after the absolute shambles of this week—
Honourable senators interjecting—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT
( Senator Back ): Order! Order! Senator Gallagher, resume your seat. Order! The speaker will be heard in silence.
Senator GALLAGHER: and of what we have seen, particularly in the last 24 hours, as the entire Senate has been kept here, sitting like lemmings, whilst the government tries to get—
Honourable senators interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Order on my right and left!

Senator GALLAGHER: its legislative program together: it does a deal, in the dark of night and throughout today, with Nick Xenophon and his team. What an absolute shambles this has been! And now we hear—
Honourable senators interjecting—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator Gallagher, resume your seat for a moment. Colleagues, we want to progress this debate and conclude it, and the behaviour that is being exhibited is not achieving that outcome. Senator Gallagher, please proceed.

Senator GALLAGHER: So—after the last 20 hours, where we have seen the government racing around, trying to cut a last-minute deal, trying to pull together the votes it has needed, for an announcement it made around 12 months ago—it has come to this: the statement from the minister today, as to which we have not even seen the deal. We have heard what the minister has said to this chamber. But—after a double sitting week where we have cut payments to families, where we have left poor children out of child care and where we have seen the government stand up for big business over people losing their penalty rates—now the final act of this Senate is to come and agree to tax cuts for businesses up to $50 billion!
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: 'Million'—$50 million.
Senator GALLAGHER: This is the priority, when you have taken money from people who require social security to help them make ends meet. And the final act is: we have got a $50-billion—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: 'Million'.
Senator GALLAGHER: a $50-million tax cut for business. That is the priority of this Senate. It is an absolute disgrace!

And we have no idea what this deal with the Nick Xenophon Team has cost. We have no idea whether there has been any work done on that. What we have heard is: a lot more reports; more reviews; more inquiries; and a whole lot of work that the government should probably have been doing anyway—that is the big win today! But the government doing what it should have been doing already—and trying to put together a power affordability and reliability strategy should be the core business of government—is the big win today!

Let us be clear on what the crossbenchers are voting for today: handing out taxpayers' money, by the billions of dollars, to this government's mates at the big end of town. They have chosen to side with the government and prioritise big business at the expense of working- and middle-class Australians. At a time when we are getting lectures from those opposite about making ends meet, about tightening the belt and about everyone else having to make sacrifices, we are going to give a big cash-splash to the big end of town. That is the priority for this government, and that is what the crossbench are voting to support today when they side with this deal.
We are not going to tolerate the hypocrisy of members of this government on issues of economic management any longer.
An honourable senator interjecting—
Senator GALLAGHER: Well, we will hear more from the government when we ask questions throughout the afternoon.
Senator Cash: 'Evening'.

Senator GALLAGHER: Well, it is still the afternoon. But the expectation is that this will cost about $19 billion—that this agreement today will hit the budget to the cost of about $19 billion, and we will wait for the government to confirm that today. So, at a time when we have got crossbenchers standing up and supporting the government on the need for fiscal restraint, they are going to wave through this bill that will hit the budget to the cost of at least $19 billion, but with the added cost of whatever the agreement is with the Nick Xenophon Team on the announcements made by the minister today, and I am sure there have been some costings done on that.

I do not think any of us will ever take a lecture from those opposite about the need to tighten belts and take money off low- and middle-income Australians, which you are going to come back to in the budget, no doubt. You have already warned us that the cuts and savings that you have made through some of your legislation program this week were just the beginning and that all of the policies that you took through the 2014-15 budget remain a priority for this government. So we expect they will come back, and we will view them in the context of what has happened this afternoon, in the event that you are about to spend $19 billion to give big businesses of up to $50 million a year—
Senator Brandis interjecting—

Senator GALLAGHER: Well, it will cost the budget, Senator Brandis. As much as you like to say it won't, it will hit the budget, and you can confirm that for me. That comes at a cost. That is what we are doing today, after the extraordinary shambles of the last 24 hours. We will not let you forget. We will not take the lectures on fiscal restraint, and we will have plenty more questions to ask during the committee stage.

Senator DASTYARI (New South Wales—Deputy Opposition Whip in the Senate) (17:11): I do not want to keep this chamber for any longer than I need to, but I have to say that a sham of a dirty deal was done out there in the corridors of parliament. This is not how $20 billion of taxpayers' funds should be spent—not through some dirty deal. You have gone out there, in the hallway, and done some dirty deal. And for what? To try and ram through an initiative. You kept us here all night. We were here last night. We stayed. We had a filibuster on race hate laws so that you could deliver a tax cut to your business mates. That is what has become of this chamber. I have to say that I think the world of Senator Xenophon. Senator Xenophon is a friend of mine.
Honourable senators interjecting—

Senator DASTYARI: He is. I know that I should not say bad things about a senator, but he is a friend of mine. The deal is for what? A bunch of reviews? A look at some initiatives? A few things the government had to do anyway to address the issues in South Australia? That the government has come in here with a cash-splash payment shows that it is literally buying votes now. That is what it is. In the trade union movement, there is a thing called a 'sign-on bonus'. What you get for workers is a sign-on bonus. Was this a sign-on bonus deal? Is that what you have been doing out there, standing in the corridor and setting some cash-splash price?

This government goes on and on about the challenges with the budget and fiscal responsibility. There perhaps is a case for those who are struggling, those on pensions, to be able to address their energy costs, but policy should not be set with dirty deals in the corridors of parliament, in the middle of the night. You are a government who has lost your agenda. You are a government who has lost your focus. You are a government who has spent a week hurting young families and trying to water down our race laws, and now you are doing tax deals for your business mates. That is what has become of your government. And today, if there was any shred of fiscal responsibility on that side of the chamber—which you, Senator Cormann, pride yourself on—all of that is now out the door, because this will be the day when you spend up to $20 billion of taxpayers' funds on a dirty deal done in the corridors of parliament to simply try and upstage the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

We all know what is going on here. Senator Cormann has been on a six-month audition for the top job, and there is nothing he will not do, no level he will not stoop to, no deal he will not do. I have to say, Senator Cormann, this is perhaps the second-worst deal you have done recently.

( Senator Back ): Senator Dastyari, please direct your comments to the chair, and I suggest that you direct your comments to the amendments before the chair.

Senator DASTYARI: This will go down as the second-worst deal—apart from being the architect of the One Nation preference deal in Western Australia—that has been done in this place. Senator CORMANN (Western Australia—Minister for Finance and Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate) (17:16): The first point I would make is that Senator Dastyari has been misleading the chamber. He is talking about the government spending money. In passing a tax reduction, the government is not spending money, because it is not the government's money. This is the money that hardworking Australians, working in businesses around Australia, have earned, and through the tax system the government decides how much of people's money we take out of their pocket in order to pay for the—
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: Senator Ludlam, a point of order?
Senator Ludlam: I would just ask you to draw the minister's attention to the question that was put directly to him by Senator Whish-Wilson. It is too late for rhetoric. We just need some answers.
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: Thank you, Senator Ludlam. We are in committee, and the question asked related to expenditure, and the minister is addressing that.

Senator CORMANN: Don't you worry, Senator: I am going to get to the bottom-line impact. But it is very important for everyone here to understand that this is not a piece of legislation that spends money. This is a piece of legislation that lets certain businesses keep more of their own money so that they can invest it in their future success, be more profitable in the future, so they can hire more Australians, so they can pay them better wages over time. This is what this is about. This is about letting businesses have more of their own money, which will boost investment, boost productivity and give people across Australia a better chance to get ahead.

Of course there is a bottom-line impact, and that has been built into our budget, and I am quite happy to answer the question by Senator Whish-Wilson. It has been built into the budget, and, as Senator Whish-Wilson knows, the 2016-17 budget—and that was confirmed in our half-yearly budget update in December—is projected to return to surplus in 2020-21. And even if the Senate had passed and had legislated the company tax cut in full, the budget was projected to be in surplus from 2020-21 onwards over the medium term, which means that the effect of the company tax cut was fully funded in our budget bottom line, and we are still in surplus after taking into account the effect of our tax cut.

Now, you asked me what the specific cost of this measure as amended is to the budget bottom line. The cost over the forward estimates is about $5.2 billion, and the cost over the medium term to 2026-27 is about $24 billion. Compared with what was of course on the table before, the bottom-line impact that is not occurring as a result of this amendment is about $25.8 billion over the medium term.

Senator WHISH-WILSON (Tasmania) (17:19): I also asked Senator Cormann what the cost of the package was. That has been written on hand notes so we cannot see it—a deal that has been done here that has kept us here for two days, costing the taxpayers millions of dollars. God knows how much it is going to cost poorer Australians in the next few years when they try to claw the money back. Can you please tell us what the cost of the package to the Nick Xenophon Team was?

Senator CORMANN (Western Australia—Minister for Finance and Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate) (17:20): Yes, I can. The first point I would make is that of course much of what the government discussed with the Nick Xenophon Team focused on policies, the policies to bring down the cost of electricity, to increase energy reliability and to do so in a way that still ensures that we can meet our emissions reduction targets and commitments that we made in the context of the Paris Agreement. A lot of what we have agreed focuses on policies to drive more affordable and more reliable energy supplies and of course to do so in as emissions efficient a way as possible.

I have read through the list of various measures, so I am not going to hold the chamber up for much longer. In terms of the measures that have a specific budget implication, I have spelled out our commitment to accelerate and secure delivery of the solar thermal project in Port Augusta through a formal call for proposals through the Australian Renewable Energy Agency and the Clean Energy Finance Corporation. I have already indicated to the chamber that the government is prepared to make available a Commonwealth concessional loan of up to $110 million at a three per cent interest rate, which is the bond rate plus one per cent. The other measure that has a cost attached to it is the one-off energy assistance payment. I stress that it is a one-off energy assistance payment. The cost of that, I am advised, is about $260 million.

Senator XENOPHON (South Australia) (17:21): I indicate that the reason why energy policy was linked to this legislation is that energy policy and energy prices are crippling Australian businesses. There must be an end point in terms of ensuring security of supply and lower prices. The process that has been agreed to is a process, but it will have an end date, because by 1 July 2018 there must be changes to the National Electricity Market rules to bring everything to a head in order to ensure that there are lower prices for our electricity and security of supply. These are fundamental issues. If you talk to businesses around the country today, they are hurting because of increases in energy prices. They are also hurting because we have not had a coherent gas policy in this country in terms of getting more gas here locally, having a public interest test and ensuring that we are not seeing gas exported overseas and so there can be intervention if there is inaction by gas companies. There is a real concern about a dominance and concentration of market power.

We need to have a proper feasibility study to see whether we can connect the Northern Territory gas pipeline to South Australia, which will in turn connect it to the rest of the grid. That is something that needs to be looked at, but in terms of the policies it will mean more local, domestic gas. It will mean a reduction of prices for consumers. It will mean that by 1 July 2018, an end date, there will be some fundamental changes to the National Electricity Market rules so that we can actually tackle these issues of security of supply and listen to and take heed of the Climate Change Authority and the Australian Energy Market Commission. They are the experts that deal with these issues.

In terms of the whole issue of saying this is all about big multinational companies, let me give you some South Australian business examples where these are not big companies. Their maximum turnover is $50 million. You have Credit Union SA, which is under the $50 million. There is Barossa Fine Foods, a smallgoods maker located in Adelaide. There is Cleanseas tuna, a commercial producer of kingfish. There is Golden North Ice Cream, between $10 million and $50 million, which is a key employer in the country town of Laura in the mid-north. There is Robern Menz, a confectionery manufacturer, which is between $10 million and $50 million. There are Beerenberg farm and B.-d. Farm Paris Creek. These are not multinationals; these are small and medium enterprises, by and large family businesses, that can actually grow in respect of this. We are not talking about the banks, Google or Facebook. We are talking about, by and large, family businesses that need this assistance.

We also will have certainty with the National Electricity Market rules with these changes. Right now there is an investment strike in this country. People are not prepared to invest in power, because of the uncertainty of policy. We now have a clear pathway with an end date of 1 July 2018 in relation to changes to those rules. The first of July 2018 is when those significant changes to the NEM rules will be in place.

We also have certainty for the solar thermal project in Port Augusta, something the government has spoken about previously. The minister may want to comment on this, but we will now have a commitment for this project to go ahead. The solar thermal plant—a demonstration plant—effectively provides baseload power or, at the very least, intermediate and peaking power. It will be a world-class demonstration in South Australia that will create a thousand jobs in its construction phase. These are all important issues and will show the rest of Australia that you can build baseload renewables, which are fundamental to dealing with issues of inertia and security of supply.

In terms of that one-off payment: things are tough for those pensioners and for those on parenting payments, and that one-off payment is important to getting people through before we get those significant changes in the National Electricity Market.
This is good for consumers. It will lower prices and deliver security of supply with that start date of the new rules on 1 July 2018.

Senator CORMANN (Western Australia—Minister for Finance and Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate) (17:26): It was remiss of me. I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments that I have moved on this bill.

Senator GALLAGHER (Australian Capital Territory—Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate) (17:26): Minister, I just have a couple of questions. In relation to the policy work that you have agreed to explore and pursue as part of the arrangement, what elements of this work were not being done by the government already?

Senator CORMANN (Western Australia—Minister for Finance and Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate) (17:27): The first point I would make is that everything we have agreed with the Nick Xenophon Team is something that the government fully stands behind and is very comfortable with because it fits with our overall policy objective, which is to improve energy affordability, to improve energy reliability and to do so in a way that helps us still meet our emissions reduction targets as agreed in Paris. So there was actually right from the start, as we engaged with the Nick Xenophon Team, a strong consensus on the objective.

We did engage in particular with the Nick Xenophon Team around the proposition of the power affordability and reliability policy. Specifically, we have agreed at the Nick Xenophon Team's request to direct AEMC and the Climate Change Authority over the next fortnight to jointly produce a report that provides advice with regard to a policy or policies to enhance power systems security and to reduce energy prices. This body of work will now feed into and enhance the Finkel review and ultimately the decisions that will have to be made around changes to the rules in the National Electricity Market. We were very pleased to engage with the Nick Xenophon Team in that regard.

The proposed approach in relation to gas retention leases is something that we have agreed to at the Nick Xenophon Team's request. Obviously the objective here is to advance and pursue the introduction of a nationally consistent, stricter use-it-or-lose-it test in the context of gas retention leases in order to help address the barriers to the commercial development of gas fields and ultimately to enhance the supply of gas, which over time, of course, would be expected to reduce energy prices.

There are a range of other changes that I have read out. I am not going to bore the chamber by reading through the comprehensive list of measures again. The Productivity Commission inquiry is something that we specifically agreed to. The price transparency measures are something that, as I have indicated to the Nick Xenophon Team, the government was already working towards. This now formalises that decision. As Senator Xenophon indicated, the solar thermal plant in Port Augusta is something that, in the lead-up to the last election, we committed ourselves to, but this now locks in a process to ensure it happens more quickly. We have, of course, put specific money on the table in the form of a concessional loan.

In relation to the work with the gas pipelines that Senator Xenophon has just talked about, obviously, we have been aware of the private sector proposal that has been assessed in the past, and we are very pleased to commit ourselves to a national interest and economic assessment and a fully-fledged feasibility study to properly assess and explore whether this project could help increase supply and reduce the cost of energy across the national electricity market. That is what we are working on.

The one-off energy assistance payment: I do not think Senator Xenophon will mind me saying that I was not all that enthusiastic about that particular proposal. But, in order to facilitate the passage of this very important reform, the government has agreed to accept this particular request. I do not really know what else I can add, as I think I have now gone several times through all of the features of the consensus that we have reached with the Nick Xenophon Team.

Senator GALLAGHER (Australian Capital Territory—Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate) (17:31): I understand that senators wish to get away, and I do not want to unreasonably delay them, but, after the unreasonable 20-hour delay we have all faced, I do have a couple of other questions. Is the government still committed to the full tax plan as outlined in last year's budget?

Senator CORMANN (Western Australia—Minister for Finance and Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate) (17:31): Of course the government is committed to our policy. This is a policy that we took to the last election; it is a policy that is reflected in the budget. Today we are legislating the first three years of what is a 10-year enterprise tax plan. If you look at the 2016-17 budget papers you will see in there that the government has made a very firm and fully funded commitment to a 10-year enterprise tax plan and, indeed, to bring down the corporate tax rate for all businesses to 25 per cent over a 10-year period.

Again, I do not want to hold up the chamber for much longer either, but, as I have previously indicated in this chamber, getting down to 25 per cent over a 10-year period will only, in 10 years time, get us into the middle of the road of business tax rates around the world. It will not put us in the lead, but at least it will remove us from the bottom of the list, where we are currently hovering. Right now Australia is becoming increasingly uncompetitive when it comes to attracting investment, and we have to ensure that we make our company tax rates more competitive again. But, of course, the government is fully committed to all of the policies that are reflected in our budget.

Senator LAMBIE (Tasmania) (17:32): We have seen how it plays out here—you take family tax cuts to feed into child care; now you are going to give $75 to certain low-income earners. Where are you taking that money from in the budget?

Senator CORMANN (Western Australia—Minister for Finance and Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate) (17:33): Obviously, we have made a commitment to a particular measure which costs $260 million—it is a one-off payment. It will be reflected in the budget on the second Tuesday in May.

Senator CORMANN (Western Australia—Minister for Finance and Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate) (17:35): For somebody who has represented the great state of Western Australia in this chamber for such a long time, it is evident that Senator Sterle does not really understand how the GST works, because none of the money raised by the GST comes to the federal government. All of the money that is raised by the GST is distributed to the states—100 per cent. The next point I would make is that it is this government that has actually stopped the drop in Western Australia's share of the GST by making a unilateral, one-off payment from the federal budget—not taking money out of the GST, but from the federal budget—of $500 million in 2015-16 and about $500 million in 2016-17 to support important infrastructure projects in Western Australia. The effect of that has been to effectively stop the drop in Western Australia's share of the GST at the 2014-15 level.

I find it very interesting that Senator Sterle keeps jumping up in relation to this issue here in the chamber. But if he were really serious he would convince his leader, Mr Shorten, to commit to a higher share of the GST payments under a Shorten-led Labor government—unless you are prepared to put your money where your mouth is, unless you, Senator Sterle, can convince your leader to take money away from South Australia. I see Senator Gallacher over there and he would be quite happy, I guess, for Mr shorten to say, 'We are going to take money away from South Australia and from Tasmania,'—I see Senator Lambie over there—and give it to Western Australia. Senator CORMANN (Western Australia—Minister for Finance and Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate) (17:38): This a government of delivery. Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Deputy Opposition Whip in the Senate) (17:40): Minister, you have referred the power affordability and reliability strategy to the AEMC and the Climate Change Authority. The AEMC's position for some time has been to recommend an emissions intensity scheme. Your government has previously ruled such a scheme out. Does this referral mean this scheme is back on the table?

Senator CORMANN (Western Australia—Minister for Finance and Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate) (17:40): No, it does not. What it means is that what is on the table is the pursuit of a power affordability and reliability policy, as I have clearly indicated to the chamber. I will remind the chamber of what the government has agreed to do. The government has agreed to direct AEMC and the Climate Change Authority, over the next fortnight, to jointly produce a report that provides advice with regard to a policy or policies to enhance power system security and to reduce energy prices, consistent with achieving our emissions reduction targets in the Paris agreement.

I pause here to say that I am sure these are objectives shared by all senators in this chamber. I believe that all of us in this chamber would share the objective that is enshrined in that particular proposition. And further, as I indicated earlier, the report will be informed by independent modelling which will be jointly commissioned by the AEMC and the Climate Change Authority and be factored into the work undertaken by Chief Scientist Finkel on behalf of COAG. The report will be presented to government by 1 June 2017, it will be made public by 15 June 2017 and it will be tabled in parliament on the next available sitting date and be taken into account by the government as it acts on the Finkel review recommendations to approve the affordability and reliability of energy supplies. Finally, and this is a very important point, the government's commitment is that, in light of the reports and reviews that I have just read you through, to pursue the implementation of a power affordability and reliability policy—again, I am sure everybody in this chamber would support a power affordability and reliability policy—which can be generated to put downward pressure on electricity prices and enhance energy reliability through relevant changes to the national electricity market rules. As Senator Xenophon has also indicated, the government has made a commitment that the implementation of such a policy will begin at the earliest possible opportunity and no later than 1 July 2018.

Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Deputy Opposition Whip in the Senate) (17:42): Minister, there is a sequence of reports and processes, including the work undertaken by the AEMC and the Climate Change Authority and then the work undertaken by Professor Finkel. If any of that work includes a recommendation for an emissions intensity scheme, will your government be willing to consider that as part of your policy development?

Senator CORMANN (Western Australia—Minister for Finance and Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate) (17:43): What the government anticipates is that we will have in front of us a power affordability and reliability policy. That is what we are looking for. We want the best possible power affordability and reliability policy. We want a policy that brings down the cost of electricity, that improves reliability and that does so in a way that it still helps us meet our emissions reduction targets and the commitments that we as a country made in the context of the Paris agreement.

I would have thought it was an entirely non-contentious proposition to pursue a policy to improve power affordability, which means of course putting downward pressure on electricity prices, and to improve reliability, which means enhancing energy reliability through relevant changes to the national electricity market rules. I would have thought that that is something everyone in this chamber can support. The government has made a very firm commitment to do exactly as we have set out and as we have committed to in the course of our conversations with the Nick Xenophon Team.

As flagged in my second reading speech to the Senate, the amendments that have been circulated in my name match Labor's very sensible and fiscally responsible election commitments—and I will be very brief, considering the hour. Labor's amendments are targeted. They are affordable. They would benefit three million small businesses. The amendments include: reducing the company tax rate to 27.5 per cent for businesses with a turnover of less than $2 million, the threshold that remains consistent with the ATO's definition of a small business; increasing the unincorporated small business tax discount from five per cent to eight per cent for businesses with a turnover of less than $2 million; and not proceeding with the increase to the small-business-entity threshold.
