Obviously, there is plenty of cash around in the budget these days. The government expects that all these great big tax cuts will give back dividends, so I am simply asking on behalf of one of the most vulnerable sectors in business, which is small businesses with a medium turnover of up to $10 million, that the government cut their tax rate from 28.5 per cent to 23.5 per cent over a five-year period. That is one per cent per year. That is what these amendments mean, and that is what I am asking for. I commend the amendments to the Senate.

Senator CORMANN (Western Australia—Minister for Finance and Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate) (18:13): These amendments are entirely inconsistent with what the Senate has already decided, and the government will not be supporting them.

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland) (18:13): I seek clarification from Minister Cormann. In your opening statement, you went into a level of detail about your negotiations with the Xenophon team. I understand that when you do these things in dark corridors, as Senator Dastyari mentioned, it is always hard to bring the precise details with you. But I am sure you did your best to outline what the three South Australian Xenophon team members wanted to deliver for their home state. But, in that address, I did not actually hear you go into any detail about what the Pauline Hanson One Nation team extracted for their votes. I am particularly interested in what the two Queensland senators were able to extract as part of their deal to support this package.

Senator CORMANN (Western Australia—Minister for Finance and Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate) (18:14): Senator Chisholm, who we all know was desperate to organise preferences from Pauline Hanson's One Nation party for the next Queensland state election, has obviously been asleep at the wheel while everybody around Australia, particularly the people in North Queensland, realised that we have been working together—this is the Liberal-National parties and, of course, Pauline Hanson's One Nation—to deliver a good outcome for the sugar industry in North Queensland. That is a matter of public record. Senator Hanson, as leader of Pauline Hanson's One Nation party, has been on the public record for some time now that her party supports business tax cuts for businesses with a turnover of up to $50 million. But I am not surprised that Senator Chisholm has not noticed that. He must have been so focused on negotiating a preference deal for the next state election that he did not pay attention to what was actually happening in the community he is meant to represent.

Senator HANSON (Queensland) (18:15): I would like to make a comment in regard to that. Let me put it on the record that One Nation did not do any 'dirty deals'. That might be your way of operating in this chamber, but no deals have been done. It is about talking common sense about policies. That is where we are coming from. It is on the record: no dirty deals. You would like to think so—but no. The sugar industry was putting a case forward long before this was actually spoken about. I was working with the canegrowers at the end of last year to get a code of conduct done. So I was pleased to see that the National Party and the Liberal Party could see the sense in helping the cane growers of North Queensland—your constituents, I might say. These are Senator Chisholm's constituents and he never took any interest in trying to represent them. So he can answer them at the ballot box at the next election. The fact is that no deals have been done—nothing whatsoever—and this was a good outcome for small businesses in Australia. In the last year, we have seen 260,000 small businesses exit the scene. That is a problem that is happening in Australia. So I think this is a good outcome for the government.

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Senator Ketter ): Before I put the question, I want to clarify for the benefit of the chamber that those in favour of Senator Lambie's amendments would vote no to the question I am about to put and those who are against Senator Lambie's amendments would vote yes. The question is that those items, as indicated on the running sheet, stand as printed.
Question agreed to.
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: The question now is that the amendments be agreed to.
Question negatived.
